\DoxyCodeLine{1933 \textcolor{comment}{=== WHAT CAN BE DETECTED WITH OptGuard INTEGRITY CHECKER =================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1934 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1935 \textcolor{comment}{Following  types  of  errors  in your target function (constraints) can be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1936 \textcolor{comment}{caught:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1937 \textcolor{comment}{a) discontinuous functions ("{}non-\/C0"{} part of the report)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1938 \textcolor{comment}{b) functions with discontinuous derivative ("{}non-\/C1"{} part of the report)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1939 \textcolor{comment}{c) errors in the analytic gradient provided by user}}

\DoxyCodeLine{1941 \textcolor{comment}{These types of errors result in optimizer  stopping  well  before reaching}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1942 \textcolor{comment}{solution (most often -\/ right after encountering discontinuity).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1943 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1944 \textcolor{comment}{Type A errors are usually  coding  errors  during  implementation  of  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1945 \textcolor{comment}{target function. Most "{}normal"{} problems involve continuous functions,  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1946 \textcolor{comment}{anyway you can't reliably optimize discontinuous function.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1947 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1948 \textcolor{comment}{Type B errors are either coding errors or (in case code itself is correct)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1949 \textcolor{comment}{evidence of the fact  that  your  problem  is  an  "{}incorrect"{}  one.  Most}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1950 \textcolor{comment}{optimizers (except for ones provided by MINNS subpackage) do  not  support}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1951 \textcolor{comment}{nonsmooth problems.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1952 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1953 \textcolor{comment}{Type C errors are coding errors which often prevent optimizer from  making}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1954 \textcolor{comment}{even one step  or result in optimizing stopping  too  early,  as  soon  as}}
\DoxyCodeLine{1955 \textcolor{comment}{actual descent direction becomes too different from one suggested by user-\/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{2216 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{2217 \textcolor{comment}{When precise analytic gradient is provided this test is more powerful than}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3362 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3363 \textcolor{comment}{        LIMITED MEMORY BFGS METHOD FOR LARGE SCALE OPTIMIZATION}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3364 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3365 \textcolor{comment}{DESCRIPTION:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3366 \textcolor{comment}{The subroutine minimizes function F(x) of N arguments by  using  a  quasi-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3367 \textcolor{comment}{Newton method (LBFGS scheme) which is optimized to use  a  minimum  amount}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3368 \textcolor{comment}{of memory.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3369 \textcolor{comment}{The subroutine generates the approximation of an inverse Hessian matrix by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3370 \textcolor{comment}{using information about the last M steps of the algorithm  (instead of N).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3371 \textcolor{comment}{It lessens a required amount of memory from a value  of  order  N\string^2  to  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3372 \textcolor{comment}{value of order 2*N*M.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3373 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3374 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3375 \textcolor{comment}{REQUIREMENTS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3376 \textcolor{comment}{Algorithm will request following information during its operation:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3377 \textcolor{comment}{* function value F and its gradient G (simultaneously) at given point X}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3378 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3379 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3380 \textcolor{comment}{USAGE:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3381 \textcolor{comment}{1. User initializes algorithm state with MinLBFGSCreate() call}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3382 \textcolor{comment}{2. User tunes solver parameters with MinLBFGSSetCond() MinLBFGSSetStpMax()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3383 \textcolor{comment}{   and other functions}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3384 \textcolor{comment}{3. User calls MinLBFGSOptimize() function which takes algorithm  state and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3385 \textcolor{comment}{   pointer (delegate, etc.) to callback function which calculates F/G.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3386 \textcolor{comment}{4. User calls MinLBFGSResults() to get solution}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3387 \textcolor{comment}{5. Optionally user may call MinLBFGSRestartFrom() to solve another problem}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3388 \textcolor{comment}{   with same N/M but another starting point and/or another function.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3389 \textcolor{comment}{   MinLBFGSRestartFrom() allows to reuse already initialized structure.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3390 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3391 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3392 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3393 \textcolor{comment}{    N       -\/   problem dimension. N>0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3394 \textcolor{comment}{    M       -\/   number of corrections in the BFGS scheme of Hessian}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3395 \textcolor{comment}{                approximation update. Recommended value:  3<=M<=7. The smaller}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3396 \textcolor{comment}{                value causes worse convergence, the bigger will  not  cause  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3397 \textcolor{comment}{                considerably better convergence, but will cause a fall in  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3398 \textcolor{comment}{                performance. M<=N.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3399 \textcolor{comment}{    X       -\/   initial solution approximation, array[0..N-\/1].}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3400 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3401 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3402 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3403 \textcolor{comment}{    State   -\/   structure which stores algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3404 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3405 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3406 \textcolor{comment}{NOTES:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3407 \textcolor{comment}{1. you may tune stopping conditions with MinLBFGSSetCond() function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3408 \textcolor{comment}{2. if target function contains exp() or other fast growing functions,  and}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3422 \textcolor{comment}{The subroutine is finite difference variant of MinLBFGSCreate().  It  uses}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3428 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3429 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3431 \textcolor{comment}{                * if given, only leading N elements of X are used}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3432 \textcolor{comment}{                * if not given, automatically determined from size of X}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3433 \textcolor{comment}{    M       -\/   number of corrections in the BFGS scheme of Hessian}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3434 \textcolor{comment}{                approximation update. Recommended value:  3<=M<=7. The smaller}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3435 \textcolor{comment}{                value causes worse convergence, the bigger will  not  cause  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3436 \textcolor{comment}{                considerably better convergence, but will cause a fall in  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3437 \textcolor{comment}{                performance. M<=N.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3438 \textcolor{comment}{    X       -\/   starting point, array[0..N-\/1].}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3439 \textcolor{comment}{    DiffStep-\/   differentiation step, >0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3440 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3441 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3442 \textcolor{comment}{    State   -\/   structure which stores algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3443 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3444 \textcolor{comment}{NOTES:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3445 \textcolor{comment}{1. algorithm uses 4-\/point central formula for differentiation.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3446 \textcolor{comment}{2. differentiation step along I-\/th axis is equal to DiffStep*S[I] where}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3447 \textcolor{comment}{   S[] is scaling vector which can be set by MinLBFGSSetScale() call.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3448 \textcolor{comment}{3. we recommend you to use moderate values of  differentiation  step.  Too}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3449 \textcolor{comment}{   large step will result in too large truncation  errors, while too small}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3450 \textcolor{comment}{   step will result in too large numerical  errors.  1.0E-\/6  can  be  good}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3451 \textcolor{comment}{   value to start with.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3452 \textcolor{comment}{4. Numerical  differentiation  is   very   inefficient  -\/   one   gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3453 \textcolor{comment}{   calculation needs 4*N function evaluations. This function will work for}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3454 \textcolor{comment}{   any N -\/ either small (1...10), moderate (10...100) or  large  (100...).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3455 \textcolor{comment}{   However, performance penalty will be too severe for any N's except  for}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3456 \textcolor{comment}{   small ones.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3457 \textcolor{comment}{   We should also say that code which relies on numerical  differentiation}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3458 \textcolor{comment}{   is   less  robust  and  precise.  LBFGS  needs  exact  gradient values.}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3461 \textcolor{comment}{   Thus  we  recommend to use this function for fast prototyping on small-\/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3677 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3678 \textcolor{comment}{These functions accept following parameters:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3679 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3680 \textcolor{comment}{    func    -\/   callback which calculates function (or merit function)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3681 \textcolor{comment}{                value func at given point x}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3682 \textcolor{comment}{    grad    -\/   callback which calculates function (or merit function)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3683 \textcolor{comment}{                value func and gradient grad at given point x}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3684 \textcolor{comment}{    rep     -\/   optional callback which is called after each iteration}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3685 \textcolor{comment}{                can be NULL}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3686 \textcolor{comment}{    ptr     -\/   optional pointer which is passed to func/grad/hess/jac/rep}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3687 \textcolor{comment}{                can be NULL}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3688 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3689 \textcolor{comment}{NOTES:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3690 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3691 \textcolor{comment}{1. This function has two different implementations: one which  uses  exact}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3692 \textcolor{comment}{   (analytical) user-\/supplied gradient,  and one which uses function value}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3693 \textcolor{comment}{   only  and  numerically  differentiates  function  in  order  to  obtain}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3695 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3696 \textcolor{comment}{   Depending  on  the  specific  function  used to create optimizer object}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3697 \textcolor{comment}{   (either MinLBFGSCreate() for analytical gradient  or  MinLBFGSCreateF()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3698 \textcolor{comment}{   for numerical differentiation) you should choose appropriate variant of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3699 \textcolor{comment}{   MinLBFGSOptimize() -\/ one  which  accepts  function  AND gradient or one}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3701 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3702 \textcolor{comment}{   Be careful to choose variant of MinLBFGSOptimize() which corresponds to}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3705 \textcolor{comment}{   function used to create optimizer.}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3711 \textcolor{comment}{   MinLBFGSCreateF() |     work                FAIL}}

\DoxyCodeLine{3737 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3738 \textcolor{comment}{This  function  activates/deactivates verification  of  the  user-\/supplied}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3739 \textcolor{comment}{analytic gradient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3740 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3741 \textcolor{comment}{Upon  activation  of  this  option  OptGuard  integrity  checker  performs}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3742 \textcolor{comment}{numerical differentiation of your target function  at  the  initial  point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3743 \textcolor{comment}{(note: future versions may also perform check  at  the  final  point)  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3744 \textcolor{comment}{compares numerical gradient with analytic one provided by you.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3745 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3746 \textcolor{comment}{If difference is too large, an error flag is set and optimization  session}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3747 \textcolor{comment}{continues. After optimization session is over, you can retrieve the report}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3748 \textcolor{comment}{which  stores  both  gradients  and  specific  components  highlighted  as}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3749 \textcolor{comment}{suspicious by the OptGuard.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3750 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3751 \textcolor{comment}{The primary OptGuard report can be retrieved with minlbfgsoptguardresults().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3752 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3753 \textcolor{comment}{IMPORTANT: gradient check is a high-\/overhead option which  will  cost  you}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3754 \textcolor{comment}{           about 3*N additional function evaluations. In many cases it may}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3755 \textcolor{comment}{           cost as much as the rest of the optimization session.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3756 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3757 \textcolor{comment}{           YOU SHOULD NOT USE IT IN THE PRODUCTION CODE UNLESS YOU WANT TO}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3758 \textcolor{comment}{           CHECK DERIVATIVES PROVIDED BY SOME THIRD PARTY.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3759 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3760 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: unlike previous incarnation of the gradient checking code,  OptGuard}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3761 \textcolor{comment}{      does NOT interrupt optimization even if it discovers bad gradient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3762 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3763 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3764 \textcolor{comment}{    State       -\/   structure used to store algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3765 \textcolor{comment}{    TestStep    -\/   verification step used for numerical differentiation:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3766 \textcolor{comment}{                    * TestStep=0 turns verification off}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3767 \textcolor{comment}{                    * TestStep>0 activates verification}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3768 \textcolor{comment}{                    You should carefully choose TestStep. Value  which  is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3769 \textcolor{comment}{                    too large (so large that  function  behavior  is  non-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3770 \textcolor{comment}{                    cubic at this scale) will lead  to  false  alarms. Too}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3771 \textcolor{comment}{                    short step will result in rounding  errors  dominating}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3772 \textcolor{comment}{                    numerical derivative.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3773 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3774 \textcolor{comment}{                    You may use different step for different parameters by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3775 \textcolor{comment}{                    means of setting scale with minlbfgssetscale().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3776 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3777 \textcolor{comment}{=== EXPLANATION ==========================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3778 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3779 \textcolor{comment}{In order to verify gradient algorithm performs following steps:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3780 \textcolor{comment}{  * two trial steps are made to X[i]-\/TestStep*S[i] and X[i]+TestStep*S[i],}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3781 \textcolor{comment}{    where X[i] is i-\/th component of the initial point and S[i] is a  scale}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3782 \textcolor{comment}{    of i-\/th parameter}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3783 \textcolor{comment}{  * F(X) is evaluated at these trial points}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3784 \textcolor{comment}{  * we perform one more evaluation in the middle point of the interval}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3785 \textcolor{comment}{  * we  build  cubic  model using function values and derivatives at trial}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3786 \textcolor{comment}{    points and we compare its prediction with actual value in  the  middle}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3787 \textcolor{comment}{    point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3788 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3789 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3790 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 15.06.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3791 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3792 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} minlbfgsoptguardgradient(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1minlbfgsstate}{minlbfgsstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \textcolor{keywordtype}{double} teststep, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
\DoxyCodeLine{3793 }
\DoxyCodeLine{3794 }
\DoxyCodeLine{3795 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3796 \textcolor{comment}{This  function  activates/deactivates nonsmoothness monitoring  option  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3797 \textcolor{comment}{the  OptGuard  integrity  checker. Smoothness  monitor  silently  observes}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3798 \textcolor{comment}{solution process and tries to detect ill-\/posed problems, i.e. ones with:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3799 \textcolor{comment}{a) discontinuous target function (non-\/C0)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3800 \textcolor{comment}{b) nonsmooth     target function (non-\/C1)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3801 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3802 \textcolor{comment}{Smoothness monitoring does NOT interrupt optimization  even if it suspects}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3803 \textcolor{comment}{that your problem is nonsmooth. It just sets corresponding  flags  in  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3804 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard report which can be retrieved after optimization is over.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3805 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3806 \textcolor{comment}{Smoothness monitoring is a moderate overhead option which often adds  less}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3807 \textcolor{comment}{than 1\% to the optimizer running time. Thus, you can use it even for large}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3808 \textcolor{comment}{scale problems.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3809 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3810 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: OptGuard does  NOT  guarantee  that  it  will  always  detect  C0/C1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3811 \textcolor{comment}{      continuity violations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3812 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3813 \textcolor{comment}{      First, minor errors are hard to  catch -\/ say, a 0.0001 difference in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3814 \textcolor{comment}{      the model values at two sides of the gap may be due to discontinuity}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3815 \textcolor{comment}{      of the model -\/ or simply because the model has changed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3816 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3817 \textcolor{comment}{      Second, C1-\/violations  are  especially  difficult  to  detect  in  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3818 \textcolor{comment}{      noninvasive way. The optimizer usually  performs  very  short  steps}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3819 \textcolor{comment}{      near the nonsmoothness, and differentiation  usually   introduces  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3820 \textcolor{comment}{      lot of numerical noise.  It  is  hard  to  tell  whether  some  tiny}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3821 \textcolor{comment}{      discontinuity in the slope is due to real nonsmoothness or just  due}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3822 \textcolor{comment}{      to numerical noise alone.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3823 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3824 \textcolor{comment}{      Our top priority was to avoid false positives, so in some rare cases}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3825 \textcolor{comment}{      minor errors may went unnoticed (however, in most cases they can  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3826 \textcolor{comment}{      spotted with restart from different initial point).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3827 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3828 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3829 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3830 \textcolor{comment}{    level   -\/   monitoring level:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3831 \textcolor{comment}{                * 0 -\/ monitoring is disabled}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3832 \textcolor{comment}{                * 1 -\/ noninvasive low-\/overhead monitoring; function values}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3833 \textcolor{comment}{                      and/or gradients are recorded, but OptGuard does not}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3834 \textcolor{comment}{                      try to perform additional evaluations  in  order  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3835 \textcolor{comment}{                      get more information about suspicious locations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3836 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3837 \textcolor{comment}{=== EXPLANATION ==========================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3838 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3839 \textcolor{comment}{One major source of headache during optimization  is  the  possibility  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3840 \textcolor{comment}{the coding errors in the target function/constraints (or their gradients).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3841 \textcolor{comment}{Such  errors   most   often   manifest   themselves  as  discontinuity  or}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3842 \textcolor{comment}{nonsmoothness of the target/constraints.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3843 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3844 \textcolor{comment}{Another frequent situation is when you try to optimize something involving}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3845 \textcolor{comment}{lots of min() and max() operations, i.e. nonsmooth target. Although not  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3846 \textcolor{comment}{coding error, it is nonsmoothness anyway -\/ and smooth  optimizers  usually}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3847 \textcolor{comment}{stop right after encountering nonsmoothness, well before reaching solution.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3848 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3849 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard integrity checker helps you to catch such situations: it monitors}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3850 \textcolor{comment}{function values/gradients being passed  to  the  optimizer  and  tries  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3851 \textcolor{comment}{errors. Upon discovering suspicious pair of points it  raises  appropriate}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3852 \textcolor{comment}{flag (and allows you to continue optimization). When optimization is done,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3853 \textcolor{comment}{you can study OptGuard result.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3854 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3855 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3856 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 21.11.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3857 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3858 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} minlbfgsoptguardsmoothness(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1minlbfgsstate}{minlbfgsstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} ae\_int\_t level, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
\DoxyCodeLine{3859 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} minlbfgsoptguardsmoothness(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1minlbfgsstate}{minlbfgsstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
\DoxyCodeLine{3860 }
\DoxyCodeLine{3861 }
\DoxyCodeLine{3862 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3863 \textcolor{comment}{Results of OptGuard integrity check, should be called  after  optimization}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3864 \textcolor{comment}{session is over.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3865 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3866 \textcolor{comment}{=== PRIMARY REPORT =======================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3867 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3868 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard performs several checks which are intended to catch common errors}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3869 \textcolor{comment}{in the implementation of nonlinear function/gradient:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3870 \textcolor{comment}{* incorrect analytic gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3871 \textcolor{comment}{* discontinuous (non-\/C0) target functions (constraints)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3872 \textcolor{comment}{* nonsmooth     (non-\/C1) target functions (constraints)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3873 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3874 \textcolor{comment}{Each of these checks is activated with appropriate function:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3875 \textcolor{comment}{* minlbfgsoptguardgradient() for gradient verification}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3876 \textcolor{comment}{* minlbfgsoptguardsmoothness() for C0/C1 checks}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3877 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3878 \textcolor{comment}{Following flags are set when these errors are suspected:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3879 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.badgradsuspected, and additionally:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3880 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradvidx for specific variable (gradient element) suspected}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3881 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradxbase, a point where gradient is tested}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3882 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgraduser, user-\/provided gradient  (stored  as  2D  matrix  with}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3883 \textcolor{comment}{    single row in order to make  report  structure  compatible  with  more}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3884 \textcolor{comment}{    complex optimizers like MinNLC or MinLM)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3885 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradnum,   reference    gradient    obtained    via   numerical}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3886 \textcolor{comment}{    differentiation (stored as  2D matrix with single row in order to make}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3887 \textcolor{comment}{    report structure compatible with more complex optimizers  like  MinNLC}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3888 \textcolor{comment}{    or MinLM)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3889 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc0suspected}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3890 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1suspected}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3891 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3892 \textcolor{comment}{=== ADDITIONAL REPORTS/LOGS ==============================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3893 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3894 \textcolor{comment}{Several different tests are performed to catch C0/C1 errors, you can  find}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3895 \textcolor{comment}{out specific test signaled error by looking to:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3896 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc0test0positive, for non-\/C0 test \#0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3897 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1test0positive, for non-\/C1 test \#0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3898 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1test1positive, for non-\/C1 test \#1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3899 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3900 \textcolor{comment}{Additional information (including line search logs)  can  be  obtained  by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3901 \textcolor{comment}{means of:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3902 \textcolor{comment}{* minlbfgsoptguardnonc1test0results()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3903 \textcolor{comment}{* minlbfgsoptguardnonc1test1results()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3904 \textcolor{comment}{which return detailed error reports, specific points where discontinuities}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3905 \textcolor{comment}{were found, and so on.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3906 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3907 \textcolor{comment}{==========================================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3908 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3909 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3910 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3911 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3912 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3913 \textcolor{comment}{    rep     -\/   generic OptGuard report;  more  detailed  reports  can  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3914 \textcolor{comment}{                retrieved with other functions.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3915 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3916 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: false negatives (nonsmooth problems are not identified as  nonsmooth}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3917 \textcolor{comment}{      ones) are possible although unlikely.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3918 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3919 \textcolor{comment}{      The reason  is  that  you  need  to  make several evaluations around}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3920 \textcolor{comment}{      nonsmoothness  in  order  to  accumulate  enough  information  about}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3921 \textcolor{comment}{      function curvature. Say, if you start right from the nonsmooth point,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3922 \textcolor{comment}{      optimizer simply won't get enough data to understand what  is  going}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3923 \textcolor{comment}{      wrong before it terminates due to abrupt changes in the  derivative.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3924 \textcolor{comment}{      It is also  possible  that  "{}unlucky"{}  step  will  move  us  to  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3925 \textcolor{comment}{      termination too quickly.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3926 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3927 \textcolor{comment}{      Our current approach is to have less than 0.1\%  false  negatives  in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3928 \textcolor{comment}{      our test examples  (measured  with  multiple  restarts  from  random}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3929 \textcolor{comment}{      points), and to have exactly 0\% false positives.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3930 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3931 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3932 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 21.11.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{3933 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{4157 \textcolor{preprocessor}{\#if defined(AE\_COMPILE\_MINBLEIC) || !defined(AE\_PARTIAL\_BUILD)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4158 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4159 \textcolor{comment}{                     BOUND CONSTRAINED OPTIMIZATION}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4160 \textcolor{comment}{       WITH ADDITIONAL LINEAR EQUALITY AND INEQUALITY CONSTRAINTS}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4161 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4162 \textcolor{comment}{DESCRIPTION:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4163 \textcolor{comment}{The  subroutine  minimizes  function   F(x)  of N arguments subject to any}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4164 \textcolor{comment}{combination of:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4165 \textcolor{comment}{* bound constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4166 \textcolor{comment}{* linear inequality constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4167 \textcolor{comment}{* linear equality constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4168 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4169 \textcolor{comment}{REQUIREMENTS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4170 \textcolor{comment}{* user must provide function value and gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4171 \textcolor{comment}{* starting point X0 must be feasible or}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4172 \textcolor{comment}{  not too far away from the feasible set}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4173 \textcolor{comment}{* grad(f) must be Lipschitz continuous on a level set:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4174 \textcolor{comment}{  L = \{ x : f(x)<=f(x0) \}}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4175 \textcolor{comment}{* function must be defined everywhere on the feasible set F}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4176 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4177 \textcolor{comment}{USAGE:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4178 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4179 \textcolor{comment}{Constrained optimization if far more complex than the unconstrained one.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4180 \textcolor{comment}{Here we give very brief outline of the BLEIC optimizer. We strongly recommend}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4181 \textcolor{comment}{you to read examples in the ALGLIB Reference Manual and to read ALGLIB User Guide}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4182 \textcolor{comment}{on optimization, which is available at http://www.alglib.net/optimization/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4183 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4184 \textcolor{comment}{1. User initializes algorithm state with MinBLEICCreate() call}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4185 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4186 \textcolor{comment}{2. USer adds boundary and/or linear constraints by calling}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4187 \textcolor{comment}{   MinBLEICSetBC() and MinBLEICSetLC() functions.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4188 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4189 \textcolor{comment}{3. User sets stopping conditions with MinBLEICSetCond().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4190 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4191 \textcolor{comment}{4. User calls MinBLEICOptimize() function which takes algorithm  state and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4192 \textcolor{comment}{   pointer (delegate, etc.) to callback function which calculates F/G.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4193 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4194 \textcolor{comment}{5. User calls MinBLEICResults() to get solution}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4195 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4196 \textcolor{comment}{6. Optionally user may call MinBLEICRestartFrom() to solve another problem}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4197 \textcolor{comment}{   with same N but another starting point.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4198 \textcolor{comment}{   MinBLEICRestartFrom() allows to reuse already initialized structure.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4199 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4200 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: if you have box-\/only constraints (no  general  linear  constraints),}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4201 \textcolor{comment}{      then MinBC optimizer can be better option. It uses  special,  faster}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4202 \textcolor{comment}{      constraint activation method, which performs better on problems with}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4203 \textcolor{comment}{      multiple constraints active at the solution.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4204 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4205 \textcolor{comment}{      On small-\/scale problems performance of MinBC is similar to  that  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4206 \textcolor{comment}{      MinBLEIC, but on large-\/scale ones (hundreds and thousands of  active}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4207 \textcolor{comment}{      constraints) it can be several times faster than MinBLEIC.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4208 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4209 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4210 \textcolor{comment}{    N       -\/   problem dimension, N>0:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4211 \textcolor{comment}{                * if given, only leading N elements of X are used}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4212 \textcolor{comment}{                * if not given, automatically determined from size ofX}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4213 \textcolor{comment}{    X       -\/   starting point, array[N]:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4214 \textcolor{comment}{                * it is better to set X to a feasible point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4215 \textcolor{comment}{                * but X can be infeasible, in which case algorithm will try}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4216 \textcolor{comment}{                  to find feasible point first, using X as initial}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4217 \textcolor{comment}{                  approximation.}}

\DoxyCodeLine{4597 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4598 \textcolor{comment}{This  function  activates/deactivates verification  of  the  user-\/supplied}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4599 \textcolor{comment}{analytic gradient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4600 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4601 \textcolor{comment}{Upon  activation  of  this  option  OptGuard  integrity  checker  performs}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4602 \textcolor{comment}{numerical differentiation of your target function  at  the  initial  point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4603 \textcolor{comment}{(note: future versions may also perform check  at  the  final  point)  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4604 \textcolor{comment}{compares numerical gradient with analytic one provided by you.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4605 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4606 \textcolor{comment}{If difference is too large, an error flag is set and optimization  session}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4607 \textcolor{comment}{continues. After optimization session is over, you can retrieve the report}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4608 \textcolor{comment}{which  stores  both  gradients  and  specific  components  highlighted  as}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4609 \textcolor{comment}{suspicious by the OptGuard.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4610 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4611 \textcolor{comment}{The primary OptGuard report can be retrieved with minbleicoptguardresults().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4612 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4613 \textcolor{comment}{IMPORTANT: gradient check is a high-\/overhead option which  will  cost  you}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4614 \textcolor{comment}{           about 3*N additional function evaluations. In many cases it may}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4615 \textcolor{comment}{           cost as much as the rest of the optimization session.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4616 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4617 \textcolor{comment}{           YOU SHOULD NOT USE IT IN THE PRODUCTION CODE UNLESS YOU WANT TO}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4618 \textcolor{comment}{           CHECK DERIVATIVES PROVIDED BY SOME THIRD PARTY.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4619 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4620 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: unlike previous incarnation of the gradient checking code,  OptGuard}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4621 \textcolor{comment}{      does NOT interrupt optimization even if it discovers bad gradient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4622 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4623 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4624 \textcolor{comment}{    State       -\/   structure used to store algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4625 \textcolor{comment}{    TestStep    -\/   verification step used for numerical differentiation:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4626 \textcolor{comment}{                    * TestStep=0 turns verification off}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4627 \textcolor{comment}{                    * TestStep>0 activates verification}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4628 \textcolor{comment}{                    You should carefully choose TestStep. Value  which  is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4629 \textcolor{comment}{                    too large (so large that  function  behavior  is  non-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4630 \textcolor{comment}{                    cubic at this scale) will lead  to  false  alarms. Too}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4631 \textcolor{comment}{                    short step will result in rounding  errors  dominating}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4632 \textcolor{comment}{                    numerical derivative.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4633 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4634 \textcolor{comment}{                    You may use different step for different parameters by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4635 \textcolor{comment}{                    means of setting scale with minbleicsetscale().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4636 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4637 \textcolor{comment}{=== EXPLANATION ==========================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4638 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4639 \textcolor{comment}{In order to verify gradient algorithm performs following steps:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4640 \textcolor{comment}{  * two trial steps are made to X[i]-\/TestStep*S[i] and X[i]+TestStep*S[i],}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4641 \textcolor{comment}{    where X[i] is i-\/th component of the initial point and S[i] is a  scale}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4642 \textcolor{comment}{    of i-\/th parameter}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4643 \textcolor{comment}{  * F(X) is evaluated at these trial points}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4644 \textcolor{comment}{  * we perform one more evaluation in the middle point of the interval}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4645 \textcolor{comment}{  * we  build  cubic  model using function values and derivatives at trial}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4646 \textcolor{comment}{    points and we compare its prediction with actual value in  the  middle}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4647 \textcolor{comment}{    point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4648 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4649 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4650 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 15.06.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4651 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{4655 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4656 \textcolor{comment}{This  function  activates/deactivates nonsmoothness monitoring  option  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4657 \textcolor{comment}{the  OptGuard  integrity  checker. Smoothness  monitor  silently  observes}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4658 \textcolor{comment}{solution process and tries to detect ill-\/posed problems, i.e. ones with:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4659 \textcolor{comment}{a) discontinuous target function (non-\/C0)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4660 \textcolor{comment}{b) nonsmooth     target function (non-\/C1)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4661 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4662 \textcolor{comment}{Smoothness monitoring does NOT interrupt optimization  even if it suspects}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4663 \textcolor{comment}{that your problem is nonsmooth. It just sets corresponding  flags  in  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4664 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard report which can be retrieved after optimization is over.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4665 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4666 \textcolor{comment}{Smoothness monitoring is a moderate overhead option which often adds  less}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4667 \textcolor{comment}{than 1\% to the optimizer running time. Thus, you can use it even for large}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4668 \textcolor{comment}{scale problems.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4669 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4670 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: OptGuard does  NOT  guarantee  that  it  will  always  detect  C0/C1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4671 \textcolor{comment}{      continuity violations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4672 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4673 \textcolor{comment}{      First, minor errors are hard to  catch -\/ say, a 0.0001 difference in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4674 \textcolor{comment}{      the model values at two sides of the gap may be due to discontinuity}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4675 \textcolor{comment}{      of the model -\/ or simply because the model has changed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4676 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4677 \textcolor{comment}{      Second, C1-\/violations  are  especially  difficult  to  detect  in  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4678 \textcolor{comment}{      noninvasive way. The optimizer usually  performs  very  short  steps}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4679 \textcolor{comment}{      near the nonsmoothness, and differentiation  usually   introduces  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4680 \textcolor{comment}{      lot of numerical noise.  It  is  hard  to  tell  whether  some  tiny}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4681 \textcolor{comment}{      discontinuity in the slope is due to real nonsmoothness or just  due}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4682 \textcolor{comment}{      to numerical noise alone.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4683 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4684 \textcolor{comment}{      Our top priority was to avoid false positives, so in some rare cases}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4685 \textcolor{comment}{      minor errors may went unnoticed (however, in most cases they can  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4686 \textcolor{comment}{      spotted with restart from different initial point).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4687 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4688 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4689 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4690 \textcolor{comment}{    level   -\/   monitoring level:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4691 \textcolor{comment}{                * 0 -\/ monitoring is disabled}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4692 \textcolor{comment}{                * 1 -\/ noninvasive low-\/overhead monitoring; function values}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4693 \textcolor{comment}{                      and/or gradients are recorded, but OptGuard does not}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4694 \textcolor{comment}{                      try to perform additional evaluations  in  order  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4695 \textcolor{comment}{                      get more information about suspicious locations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4696 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4697 \textcolor{comment}{=== EXPLANATION ==========================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4698 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4699 \textcolor{comment}{One major source of headache during optimization  is  the  possibility  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4700 \textcolor{comment}{the coding errors in the target function/constraints (or their gradients).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4701 \textcolor{comment}{Such  errors   most   often   manifest   themselves  as  discontinuity  or}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4702 \textcolor{comment}{nonsmoothness of the target/constraints.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4703 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4704 \textcolor{comment}{Another frequent situation is when you try to optimize something involving}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4705 \textcolor{comment}{lots of min() and max() operations, i.e. nonsmooth target. Although not  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4706 \textcolor{comment}{coding error, it is nonsmoothness anyway -\/ and smooth  optimizers  usually}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4707 \textcolor{comment}{stop right after encountering nonsmoothness, well before reaching solution.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4708 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4709 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard integrity checker helps you to catch such situations: it monitors}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4710 \textcolor{comment}{function values/gradients being passed  to  the  optimizer  and  tries  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4711 \textcolor{comment}{errors. Upon discovering suspicious pair of points it  raises  appropriate}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4712 \textcolor{comment}{flag (and allows you to continue optimization). When optimization is done,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4713 \textcolor{comment}{you can study OptGuard result.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4714 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4715 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4716 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 21.11.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4717 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4718 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} minbleicoptguardsmoothness(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1minbleicstate}{minbleicstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} ae\_int\_t level, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
\DoxyCodeLine{4719 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} minbleicoptguardsmoothness(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1minbleicstate}{minbleicstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}

\DoxyCodeLine{4722 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4723 \textcolor{comment}{Results of OptGuard integrity check, should be called  after  optimization}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4724 \textcolor{comment}{session is over.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4725 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4726 \textcolor{comment}{=== PRIMARY REPORT =======================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4727 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4728 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard performs several checks which are intended to catch common errors}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4729 \textcolor{comment}{in the implementation of nonlinear function/gradient:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4730 \textcolor{comment}{* incorrect analytic gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4731 \textcolor{comment}{* discontinuous (non-\/C0) target functions (constraints)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4732 \textcolor{comment}{* nonsmooth     (non-\/C1) target functions (constraints)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4733 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4734 \textcolor{comment}{Each of these checks is activated with appropriate function:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{4735 \textcolor{comment}{* minbleicoptguardgradient() for gradient verification}}

\DoxyCodeLine{5258 \textcolor{comment}{ALGORITHM FEATURES:}}

\DoxyCodeLine{5543 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5544 \textcolor{comment}{ALGORITHM LIMITATIONS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5545 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5546 \textcolor{comment}{* this algorithm may handle moderate number  of dense constraints, usually}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5547 \textcolor{comment}{  no more than a thousand of dense ones without losing its efficiency.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5548 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5549 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5550 \textcolor{comment}{    State   -\/   structure which stores algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5551 \textcolor{comment}{    Eps     -\/   >=0, stopping criteria. The algorithm stops  when   primal}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5552 \textcolor{comment}{                and dual infeasiblities as well as complementarity gap are}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5553 \textcolor{comment}{                less than Eps.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5554 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5555 \textcolor{comment}{IT IS VERY IMPORTANT TO CALL minqpsetscale() WHEN YOU USE THIS  ALGORITHM}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5556 \textcolor{comment}{BECAUSE ITS CONVERGENCE PROPERTIES AND STOPPING CRITERIA ARE SCALE-\/DEPENDENT!}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5557 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5558 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: Passing EpsX=0 will lead to automatic selection of small epsilon.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5559 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5560 \textcolor{comment}{===== TRACING IPM SOLVER =================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5561 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5562 \textcolor{comment}{IPM solver supports advanced tracing capabilities. You can trace algorithm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5563 \textcolor{comment}{output by specifying following trace symbols (case-\/insensitive)  by  means}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5564 \textcolor{comment}{of trace\_file() call:}}

\DoxyCodeLine{5567 \textcolor{comment}{                  N-\/dimensional quantities like search directions are  NOT}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5568 \textcolor{comment}{                  printed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5569 \textcolor{comment}{* 'IPM.DETAILED'-\/ for output of points being visited and search directions}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5570 \textcolor{comment}{                  This  symbol  also  implicitly  defines  'IPM'. You  can}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5571 \textcolor{comment}{                  control output format by additionally specifying:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5572 \textcolor{comment}{                  * nothing     to output in  6-\/digit exponential format}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5573 \textcolor{comment}{                  * 'PREC.E15'  to output in 15-\/digit exponential format}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5574 \textcolor{comment}{                  * 'PREC.F6'   to output in  6-\/digit fixed-\/point format}}

\DoxyCodeLine{5576 \textcolor{comment}{By default trace is disabled and adds  no  overhead  to  the  optimization}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5577 \textcolor{comment}{process. However, specifying any of the symbols adds some  formatting  and}}

\DoxyCodeLine{5585 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{5591 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5592 \textcolor{comment}{This function tells solver to use QuickQP  algorithm:  special  extra-\/fast}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5593 \textcolor{comment}{algorithm for problems with box-\/only constrants. It may  solve  non-\/convex}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5594 \textcolor{comment}{problems as long as they are bounded from below under constraints.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5595 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5596 \textcolor{comment}{ALGORITHM FEATURES:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5597 \textcolor{comment}{* several times faster than DENSE-\/IPM when running on box-\/only problem}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5598 \textcolor{comment}{* utilizes accelerated methods for activation of constraints.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5599 \textcolor{comment}{* supports dense and sparse QP problems}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5600 \textcolor{comment}{* supports ONLY box constraints; general linear constraints are NOT}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5601 \textcolor{comment}{  supported by this solver}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5602 \textcolor{comment}{* can solve all types of problems  (convex,  semidefinite,  nonconvex)  as}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5603 \textcolor{comment}{  long as they are bounded from below under constraints.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5604 \textcolor{comment}{  Say, it is possible to solve "{}min\{-\/x\string^2\} subject to -\/1<=x<=+1"{}.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5605 \textcolor{comment}{  In convex/semidefinite case global minimum  is  returned,  in  nonconvex}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5606 \textcolor{comment}{  case -\/ algorithm returns one of the local minimums.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5607 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5608 \textcolor{comment}{ALGORITHM OUTLINE:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5609 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5610 \textcolor{comment}{* algorithm  performs  two kinds of iterations: constrained CG  iterations}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5611 \textcolor{comment}{  and constrained Newton iterations}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5612 \textcolor{comment}{* initially it performs small number of constrained CG  iterations,  which}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5613 \textcolor{comment}{  can efficiently activate/deactivate multiple constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5614 \textcolor{comment}{* after CG phase algorithm tries to calculate Cholesky  decomposition  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5615 \textcolor{comment}{  to perform several constrained Newton steps. If  Cholesky  decomposition}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5616 \textcolor{comment}{  failed (matrix is indefinite even under constraints),  we  perform  more}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5617 \textcolor{comment}{  CG iterations until we converge to such set of constraints  that  system}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5618 \textcolor{comment}{  matrix becomes  positive  definite.  Constrained  Newton  steps  greatly}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5619 \textcolor{comment}{  increase convergence speed and precision.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5620 \textcolor{comment}{* algorithm interleaves CG and Newton iterations which  allows  to  handle}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5621 \textcolor{comment}{  indefinite matrices (CG phase) and quickly converge after final  set  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5622 \textcolor{comment}{  constraints is found (Newton phase). Combination of CG and Newton phases}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5623 \textcolor{comment}{  is called "{}outer iteration"{}.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5624 \textcolor{comment}{* it is possible to turn off Newton  phase  (beneficial  for  semidefinite}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5625 \textcolor{comment}{  problems -\/ Cholesky decomposition will fail too often)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5626 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5627 \textcolor{comment}{ALGORITHM LIMITATIONS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5628 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5629 \textcolor{comment}{* algorithm does not support general  linear  constraints;  only  box ones}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5630 \textcolor{comment}{  are supported}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5631 \textcolor{comment}{* Cholesky decomposition for sparse problems  is  performed  with  Skyline}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5632 \textcolor{comment}{  Cholesky solver, which is intended for low-\/profile matrices. No profile-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5633 \textcolor{comment}{  reducing reordering of variables is performed in this version of ALGLIB.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5634 \textcolor{comment}{* problems with near-\/zero negative eigenvalues (or exacty zero  ones)  may}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5635 \textcolor{comment}{  experience about 2-\/3x performance penalty. The reason is  that  Cholesky}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5636 \textcolor{comment}{  decomposition can not be performed until we identify directions of  zero}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5637 \textcolor{comment}{  and negative curvature and activate corresponding boundary constraints -\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5638 \textcolor{comment}{  but we need a lot of trial and errors because these directions  are hard}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5639 \textcolor{comment}{  to notice in the matrix spectrum.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5640 \textcolor{comment}{  In this case you may turn off Newton phase of algorithm.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5641 \textcolor{comment}{  Large negative eigenvalues  are  not  an  issue,  so  highly  non-\/convex}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5642 \textcolor{comment}{  problems can be solved very efficiently.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5643 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5644 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5645 \textcolor{comment}{    State   -\/   structure which stores algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5646 \textcolor{comment}{    EpsG    -\/   >=0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5647 \textcolor{comment}{                The  subroutine  finishes  its  work   if   the  condition}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5648 \textcolor{comment}{                |v|<EpsG is satisfied, where:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5649 \textcolor{comment}{                * |.| means Euclidian norm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5650 \textcolor{comment}{                * v -\/ scaled constrained gradient vector, v[i]=g[i]*s[i]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5651 \textcolor{comment}{                * g -\/ gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5652 \textcolor{comment}{                * s -\/ scaling coefficients set by MinQPSetScale()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5653 \textcolor{comment}{    EpsF    -\/   >=0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5654 \textcolor{comment}{                The  subroutine  finishes its work if exploratory steepest}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5655 \textcolor{comment}{                descent  step  on  k+1-\/th iteration  satisfies   following}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5656 \textcolor{comment}{                condition:  |F(k+1)-\/F(k)|<=EpsF*max\{|F(k)|,|F(k+1)|,1\}}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5657 \textcolor{comment}{    EpsX    -\/   >=0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5658 \textcolor{comment}{                The  subroutine  finishes its work if exploratory steepest}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5659 \textcolor{comment}{                descent  step  on  k+1-\/th iteration  satisfies   following}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5660 \textcolor{comment}{                condition:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5661 \textcolor{comment}{                * |.| means Euclidian norm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5662 \textcolor{comment}{                * v -\/ scaled step vector, v[i]=dx[i]/s[i]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5663 \textcolor{comment}{                * dx -\/ step vector, dx=X(k+1)-\/X(k)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5664 \textcolor{comment}{                * s -\/ scaling coefficients set by MinQPSetScale()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5665 \textcolor{comment}{    MaxOuterIts-\/maximum number of OUTER iterations.  One  outer  iteration}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5666 \textcolor{comment}{                includes some amount of CG iterations (from 5 to  \string~N)  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5667 \textcolor{comment}{                one or several (usually small amount) Newton steps.  Thus,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5668 \textcolor{comment}{                one outer iteration has high cost, but can greatly  reduce}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5669 \textcolor{comment}{                funcation value.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5670 \textcolor{comment}{                Use 0 if you do not want to limit number of outer iterations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5671 \textcolor{comment}{    UseNewton-\/  use Newton phase or not:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5672 \textcolor{comment}{                * Newton phase improves performance of  positive  definite}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5673 \textcolor{comment}{                  dense problems (about 2 times improvement can be observed)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5674 \textcolor{comment}{                * can result in some performance penalty  on  semidefinite}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5675 \textcolor{comment}{                  or slightly negative definite  problems  -\/  each  Newton}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5676 \textcolor{comment}{                  phase will bring no improvement (Cholesky failure),  but}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5677 \textcolor{comment}{                  still will require computational time.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5678 \textcolor{comment}{                * if you doubt, you can turn off this  phase  -\/  optimizer}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5679 \textcolor{comment}{                  will retain its most of its high speed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5680 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5681 \textcolor{comment}{IT IS VERY IMPORTANT TO CALL MinQPSetScale() WHEN YOU USE THIS  ALGORITHM}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5682 \textcolor{comment}{BECAUSE ITS STOPPING CRITERIA ARE SCALE-\/DEPENDENT!}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5683 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5684 \textcolor{comment}{Passing EpsG=0, EpsF=0 and EpsX=0 and MaxIts=0 (simultaneously) will lead}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5685 \textcolor{comment}{to automatic stopping criterion selection (presently it is  small    step}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5686 \textcolor{comment}{length, but it may change in the future versions of ALGLIB).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5687 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5688 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5689 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 22.05.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5690 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{5691 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} minqpsetalgoquickqp(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1minqpstate}{minqpstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \textcolor{keywordtype}{double} epsg, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \textcolor{keywordtype}{double} epsf, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \textcolor{keywordtype}{double} epsx, \textcolor{keyword}{const} ae\_int\_t maxouterits, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \textcolor{keywordtype}{bool} usenewton, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}

\DoxyCodeLine{7020 \textcolor{comment}{NOTES:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7021 \textcolor{comment}{1. algorithm uses 4-\/point central formula for differentiation.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7022 \textcolor{comment}{2. differentiation step along I-\/th axis is equal to DiffStep*S[I] where}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7024 \textcolor{comment}{3. we recommend you to use moderate values of  differentiation  step.  Too}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7027 \textcolor{comment}{   value to start with.}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7297 \textcolor{comment}{   Depending  on  the  specific  function  used to create optimizer object}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7338 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7339 \textcolor{comment}{This  function  activates/deactivates verification  of  the  user-\/supplied}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7340 \textcolor{comment}{analytic gradient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7341 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7342 \textcolor{comment}{Upon  activation  of  this  option  OptGuard  integrity  checker  performs}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7343 \textcolor{comment}{numerical differentiation of your target function  at  the  initial  point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7344 \textcolor{comment}{(note: future versions may also perform check  at  the  final  point)  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7345 \textcolor{comment}{compares numerical gradient with analytic one provided by you.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7346 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7347 \textcolor{comment}{If difference is too large, an error flag is set and optimization  session}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7348 \textcolor{comment}{continues. After optimization session is over, you can retrieve the report}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7349 \textcolor{comment}{which  stores  both  gradients  and  specific  components  highlighted  as}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7350 \textcolor{comment}{suspicious by the OptGuard.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7351 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7352 \textcolor{comment}{The primary OptGuard report can be retrieved with mincgoptguardresults().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7353 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7354 \textcolor{comment}{IMPORTANT: gradient check is a high-\/overhead option which  will  cost  you}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7355 \textcolor{comment}{           about 3*N additional function evaluations. In many cases it may}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7356 \textcolor{comment}{           cost as much as the rest of the optimization session.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7357 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7358 \textcolor{comment}{           YOU SHOULD NOT USE IT IN THE PRODUCTION CODE UNLESS YOU WANT TO}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7359 \textcolor{comment}{           CHECK DERIVATIVES PROVIDED BY SOME THIRD PARTY.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7360 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7361 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: unlike previous incarnation of the gradient checking code,  OptGuard}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7362 \textcolor{comment}{      does NOT interrupt optimization even if it discovers bad gradient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7363 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7364 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7365 \textcolor{comment}{    State       -\/   structure used to store algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7366 \textcolor{comment}{    TestStep    -\/   verification step used for numerical differentiation:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7367 \textcolor{comment}{                    * TestStep=0 turns verification off}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7368 \textcolor{comment}{                    * TestStep>0 activates verification}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7369 \textcolor{comment}{                    You should carefully choose TestStep. Value  which  is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7370 \textcolor{comment}{                    too large (so large that  function  behavior  is  non-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7371 \textcolor{comment}{                    cubic at this scale) will lead  to  false  alarms. Too}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7372 \textcolor{comment}{                    short step will result in rounding  errors  dominating}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7373 \textcolor{comment}{                    numerical derivative.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7374 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7375 \textcolor{comment}{                    You may use different step for different parameters by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7376 \textcolor{comment}{                    means of setting scale with mincgsetscale().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7377 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7378 \textcolor{comment}{=== EXPLANATION ==========================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7379 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7380 \textcolor{comment}{In order to verify gradient algorithm performs following steps:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7381 \textcolor{comment}{  * two trial steps are made to X[i]-\/TestStep*S[i] and X[i]+TestStep*S[i],}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7382 \textcolor{comment}{    where X[i] is i-\/th component of the initial point and S[i] is a  scale}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7383 \textcolor{comment}{    of i-\/th parameter}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7384 \textcolor{comment}{  * F(X) is evaluated at these trial points}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7385 \textcolor{comment}{  * we perform one more evaluation in the middle point of the interval}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7386 \textcolor{comment}{  * we  build  cubic  model using function values and derivatives at trial}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7387 \textcolor{comment}{    points and we compare its prediction with actual value in  the  middle}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7388 \textcolor{comment}{    point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7389 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7390 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7391 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 15.06.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7392 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7393 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} mincgoptguardgradient(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1mincgstate}{mincgstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \textcolor{keywordtype}{double} teststep, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
\DoxyCodeLine{7394 }
