\DoxyCodeLine{7396 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7397 \textcolor{comment}{This  function  activates/deactivates nonsmoothness monitoring  option  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7398 \textcolor{comment}{the  OptGuard  integrity  checker. Smoothness  monitor  silently  observes}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7399 \textcolor{comment}{solution process and tries to detect ill-\/posed problems, i.e. ones with:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7400 \textcolor{comment}{a) discontinuous target function (non-\/C0)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7401 \textcolor{comment}{b) nonsmooth     target function (non-\/C1)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7402 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7403 \textcolor{comment}{Smoothness monitoring does NOT interrupt optimization  even if it suspects}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7404 \textcolor{comment}{that your problem is nonsmooth. It just sets corresponding  flags  in  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7405 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard report which can be retrieved after optimization is over.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7406 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7407 \textcolor{comment}{Smoothness monitoring is a moderate overhead option which often adds  less}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7408 \textcolor{comment}{than 1\% to the optimizer running time. Thus, you can use it even for large}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7409 \textcolor{comment}{scale problems.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7410 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7411 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: OptGuard does  NOT  guarantee  that  it  will  always  detect  C0/C1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7412 \textcolor{comment}{      continuity violations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7413 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7414 \textcolor{comment}{      First, minor errors are hard to  catch -\/ say, a 0.0001 difference in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7415 \textcolor{comment}{      the model values at two sides of the gap may be due to discontinuity}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7416 \textcolor{comment}{      of the model -\/ or simply because the model has changed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7417 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7418 \textcolor{comment}{      Second, C1-\/violations  are  especially  difficult  to  detect  in  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7419 \textcolor{comment}{      noninvasive way. The optimizer usually  performs  very  short  steps}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7420 \textcolor{comment}{      near the nonsmoothness, and differentiation  usually   introduces  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7421 \textcolor{comment}{      lot of numerical noise.  It  is  hard  to  tell  whether  some  tiny}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7422 \textcolor{comment}{      discontinuity in the slope is due to real nonsmoothness or just  due}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7423 \textcolor{comment}{      to numerical noise alone.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7424 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7425 \textcolor{comment}{      Our top priority was to avoid false positives, so in some rare cases}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7426 \textcolor{comment}{      minor errors may went unnoticed (however, in most cases they can  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7427 \textcolor{comment}{      spotted with restart from different initial point).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7428 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7429 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7430 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7431 \textcolor{comment}{    level   -\/   monitoring level:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7432 \textcolor{comment}{                * 0 -\/ monitoring is disabled}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7433 \textcolor{comment}{                * 1 -\/ noninvasive low-\/overhead monitoring; function values}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7434 \textcolor{comment}{                      and/or gradients are recorded, but OptGuard does not}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7435 \textcolor{comment}{                      try to perform additional evaluations  in  order  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7436 \textcolor{comment}{                      get more information about suspicious locations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7437 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7438 \textcolor{comment}{=== EXPLANATION ==========================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7439 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7440 \textcolor{comment}{One major source of headache during optimization  is  the  possibility  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7441 \textcolor{comment}{the coding errors in the target function/constraints (or their gradients).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7442 \textcolor{comment}{Such  errors   most   often   manifest   themselves  as  discontinuity  or}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7443 \textcolor{comment}{nonsmoothness of the target/constraints.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7444 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7445 \textcolor{comment}{Another frequent situation is when you try to optimize something involving}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7446 \textcolor{comment}{lots of min() and max() operations, i.e. nonsmooth target. Although not  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7447 \textcolor{comment}{coding error, it is nonsmoothness anyway -\/ and smooth  optimizers  usually}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7448 \textcolor{comment}{stop right after encountering nonsmoothness, well before reaching solution.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7449 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7450 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard integrity checker helps you to catch such situations: it monitors}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7451 \textcolor{comment}{function values/gradients being passed  to  the  optimizer  and  tries  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7452 \textcolor{comment}{errors. Upon discovering suspicious pair of points it  raises  appropriate}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7453 \textcolor{comment}{flag (and allows you to continue optimization). When optimization is done,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7454 \textcolor{comment}{you can study OptGuard result.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7455 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7456 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7457 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 21.11.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7458 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7459 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} mincgoptguardsmoothness(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1mincgstate}{mincgstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} ae\_int\_t level, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
\DoxyCodeLine{7460 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} mincgoptguardsmoothness(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1mincgstate}{mincgstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
\DoxyCodeLine{7461 }
\DoxyCodeLine{7462 }
\DoxyCodeLine{7463 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7464 \textcolor{comment}{Results of OptGuard integrity check, should be called  after  optimization}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7465 \textcolor{comment}{session is over.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7466 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7467 \textcolor{comment}{=== PRIMARY REPORT =======================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7468 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7469 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard performs several checks which are intended to catch common errors}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7470 \textcolor{comment}{in the implementation of nonlinear function/gradient:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7471 \textcolor{comment}{* incorrect analytic gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7472 \textcolor{comment}{* discontinuous (non-\/C0) target functions (constraints)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7473 \textcolor{comment}{* nonsmooth     (non-\/C1) target functions (constraints)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7474 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7475 \textcolor{comment}{Each of these checks is activated with appropriate function:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7476 \textcolor{comment}{* mincgoptguardgradient() for gradient verification}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7477 \textcolor{comment}{* mincgoptguardsmoothness() for C0/C1 checks}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7478 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7479 \textcolor{comment}{Following flags are set when these errors are suspected:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7480 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.badgradsuspected, and additionally:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7481 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradvidx for specific variable (gradient element) suspected}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7482 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradxbase, a point where gradient is tested}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7483 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgraduser, user-\/provided gradient  (stored  as  2D  matrix  with}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7484 \textcolor{comment}{    single row in order to make  report  structure  compatible  with  more}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7485 \textcolor{comment}{    complex optimizers like MinNLC or MinLM)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7486 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradnum,   reference    gradient    obtained    via   numerical}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7487 \textcolor{comment}{    differentiation (stored as  2D matrix with single row in order to make}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7488 \textcolor{comment}{    report structure compatible with more complex optimizers  like  MinNLC}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7489 \textcolor{comment}{    or MinLM)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7490 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc0suspected}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7491 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1suspected}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7492 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7493 \textcolor{comment}{=== ADDITIONAL REPORTS/LOGS ==============================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7494 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7495 \textcolor{comment}{Several different tests are performed to catch C0/C1 errors, you can  find}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7496 \textcolor{comment}{out specific test signaled error by looking to:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7497 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc0test0positive, for non-\/C0 test \#0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7498 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1test0positive, for non-\/C1 test \#0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7499 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1test1positive, for non-\/C1 test \#1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7500 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7501 \textcolor{comment}{Additional information (including line search logs)  can  be  obtained  by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7502 \textcolor{comment}{means of:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7503 \textcolor{comment}{* mincgoptguardnonc1test0results()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7504 \textcolor{comment}{* mincgoptguardnonc1test1results()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7505 \textcolor{comment}{which return detailed error reports, specific points where discontinuities}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7506 \textcolor{comment}{were found, and so on.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7507 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7508 \textcolor{comment}{==========================================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7509 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7510 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7511 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7512 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7513 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7514 \textcolor{comment}{    rep     -\/   generic OptGuard report;  more  detailed  reports  can  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7515 \textcolor{comment}{                retrieved with other functions.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7516 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7517 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: false negatives (nonsmooth problems are not identified as  nonsmooth}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7518 \textcolor{comment}{      ones) are possible although unlikely.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7519 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7520 \textcolor{comment}{      The reason  is  that  you  need  to  make several evaluations around}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7521 \textcolor{comment}{      nonsmoothness  in  order  to  accumulate  enough  information  about}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7522 \textcolor{comment}{      function curvature. Say, if you start right from the nonsmooth point,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7523 \textcolor{comment}{      optimizer simply won't get enough data to understand what  is  going}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7524 \textcolor{comment}{      wrong before it terminates due to abrupt changes in the  derivative.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7525 \textcolor{comment}{      It is also  possible  that  "{}unlucky"{}  step  will  move  us  to  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7526 \textcolor{comment}{      termination too quickly.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7527 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7528 \textcolor{comment}{      Our current approach is to have less than 0.1\%  false  negatives  in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7529 \textcolor{comment}{      our test examples  (measured  with  multiple  restarts  from  random}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7530 \textcolor{comment}{      points), and to have exactly 0\% false positives.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7531 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7532 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7533 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 21.11.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7534 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7535 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} mincgoptguardresults(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1mincgstate}{mincgstate}} \&state, \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1optguardreport}{optguardreport}} \&rep, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
\DoxyCodeLine{7536 }
\DoxyCodeLine{7537 }
\DoxyCodeLine{7538 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7539 \textcolor{comment}{Detailed results of the OptGuard integrity check for nonsmoothness test \#0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7540 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7541 \textcolor{comment}{Nonsmoothness (non-\/C1) test \#0 studies  function  values  (not  gradient!)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7542 \textcolor{comment}{obtained during line searches and monitors  behavior  of  the  directional}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7543 \textcolor{comment}{derivative estimate.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7544 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7545 \textcolor{comment}{This test is less powerful than test \#1, but it does  not  depend  on  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7546 \textcolor{comment}{gradient values and thus it is more robust against artifacts introduced by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7547 \textcolor{comment}{numerical differentiation.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7548 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7549 \textcolor{comment}{Two reports are returned:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7550 \textcolor{comment}{* a "{}strongest"{} one, corresponding  to  line   search  which  had  highest}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7551 \textcolor{comment}{  value of the nonsmoothness indicator}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7552 \textcolor{comment}{* a "{}longest"{} one, corresponding to line search which  had  more  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7553 \textcolor{comment}{  evaluations, and thus is more detailed}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7554 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7555 \textcolor{comment}{In both cases following fields are returned:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7556 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7557 \textcolor{comment}{* positive -\/ is TRUE  when test flagged suspicious point;  FALSE  if  test}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7558 \textcolor{comment}{  did not notice anything (in the latter cases fields below are empty).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7559 \textcolor{comment}{* x0[], d[] -\/ arrays of length N which store initial point  and  direction}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7560 \textcolor{comment}{  for line search (d[] can be normalized, but does not have to)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7561 \textcolor{comment}{* stp[], f[] -\/ arrays of length CNT which store step lengths and  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7562 \textcolor{comment}{  values at these points; f[i] is evaluated in x0+stp[i]*d.}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7839 \textcolor{comment}{* this  algorithm  is  our implementation  of  interior  point  method  as}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7842 \textcolor{comment}{* like all interior point methods, this algorithm  tends  to  converge  in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7843 \textcolor{comment}{  roughly same number of iterations (between 15 and 50) independently from}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7844 \textcolor{comment}{  the problem dimensionality}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7845 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7846 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7848 \textcolor{comment}{    Eps     -\/   stopping condition, Eps>=0:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7849 \textcolor{comment}{                * should be small number about 1E-\/7 or 1E-\/8.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7850 \textcolor{comment}{                * zero value means that solver automatically selects good}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7851 \textcolor{comment}{                  value (can be different in different ALGLIB versions)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7852 \textcolor{comment}{                * default value is zero}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7853 \textcolor{comment}{                Algorithm  stops  when  primal  error  AND  dual error AND}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7854 \textcolor{comment}{                duality gap are less than Eps.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7855 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7856 \textcolor{comment}{===== TRACING IPM SOLVER =================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7857 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7858 \textcolor{comment}{IPM solver supports advanced tracing capabilities. You can trace algorithm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7859 \textcolor{comment}{output by specifying following trace symbols (case-\/insensitive)  by  means}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7861 \textcolor{comment}{* 'IPM'         -\/ for basic trace of algorithm  steps and decisions.  Only}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7863 \textcolor{comment}{                  N-\/dimensional quantities like search directions are  NOT}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7865 \textcolor{comment}{* 'IPM.DETAILED'-\/ for output of points being visited and search directions}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7866 \textcolor{comment}{                  This  symbol  also  implicitly  defines  'IPM'. You  can}}
\DoxyCodeLine{7867 \textcolor{comment}{                  control output format by additionally specifying:}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7869 \textcolor{comment}{                  * 'PREC.E15'  to output in 15-\/digit exponential format}}

\DoxyCodeLine{7872 \textcolor{comment}{By default trace is disabled and adds  no  overhead  to  the  optimization}}

\DoxyCodeLine{8269 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8270 \textcolor{comment}{                  NONLINEARLY  CONSTRAINED  OPTIMIZATION}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8271 \textcolor{comment}{            WITH PRECONDITIONED AUGMENTED LAGRANGIAN ALGORITHM}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8272 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8273 \textcolor{comment}{DESCRIPTION:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8274 \textcolor{comment}{The  subroutine  minimizes  function   F(x)  of N arguments subject to any}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8275 \textcolor{comment}{combination of:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8276 \textcolor{comment}{* bound constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8277 \textcolor{comment}{* linear inequality constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8278 \textcolor{comment}{* linear equality constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8279 \textcolor{comment}{* nonlinear equality constraints Gi(x)=0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8280 \textcolor{comment}{* nonlinear inequality constraints Hi(x)<=0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8281 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8282 \textcolor{comment}{REQUIREMENTS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8283 \textcolor{comment}{* user must provide function value and gradient for F(), H(), G()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8284 \textcolor{comment}{* starting point X0 must be feasible or not too far away from the feasible}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8285 \textcolor{comment}{  set}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8286 \textcolor{comment}{* F(), G(), H() are continuously differentiable on the  feasible  set  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8287 \textcolor{comment}{  its neighborhood}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8288 \textcolor{comment}{* nonlinear constraints G() and H() must have non-\/zero gradient at  G(x)=0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8289 \textcolor{comment}{  and at H(x)=0. Say, constraint like x\string^2>=1 is supported, but x\string^2>=0   is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8290 \textcolor{comment}{  NOT supported.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8291 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8292 \textcolor{comment}{USAGE:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8293 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8294 \textcolor{comment}{Constrained optimization if far more complex than the  unconstrained  one.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8295 \textcolor{comment}{Nonlinearly constrained optimization is one of the most esoteric numerical}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8296 \textcolor{comment}{procedures.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8297 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8298 \textcolor{comment}{Here we give very brief outline  of  the  MinNLC  optimizer.  We  strongly}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8299 \textcolor{comment}{recommend you to study examples in the ALGLIB Reference Manual and to read}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8300 \textcolor{comment}{ALGLIB User Guide on optimization, which is available at}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8301 \textcolor{comment}{http://www.alglib.net/optimization/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8302 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8303 \textcolor{comment}{1. User initializes algorithm state with MinNLCCreate() call  and  chooses}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8304 \textcolor{comment}{   what NLC solver to use. There is some solver which is used by  default,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8305 \textcolor{comment}{   with default settings, but you should NOT rely on  default  choice.  It}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8306 \textcolor{comment}{   may change in future releases of ALGLIB without notice, and no one  can}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8307 \textcolor{comment}{   guarantee that new solver will be  able  to  solve  your  problem  with}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8308 \textcolor{comment}{   default settings.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8309 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8310 \textcolor{comment}{   From the other side, if you choose solver explicitly, you can be pretty}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8311 \textcolor{comment}{   sure that it will work with new ALGLIB releases.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8312 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8313 \textcolor{comment}{   In the current release following solvers can be used:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8314 \textcolor{comment}{   * SQP solver, recommended for medium-\/scale problems (less than thousand}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8315 \textcolor{comment}{     of variables) with hard-\/to-\/evaluate target functions.  Requires  less}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8316 \textcolor{comment}{     function  evaluations  than  other  solvers  but  each  step involves}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8317 \textcolor{comment}{     solution of QP subproblem, so running time may be higher than that of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8318 \textcolor{comment}{     AUL (another recommended option). Activated  with  minnlcsetalgosqp()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8319 \textcolor{comment}{     function.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8320 \textcolor{comment}{   * AUL solver with dense  preconditioner,  recommended  for  large-\/scale}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8321 \textcolor{comment}{     problems or for problems  with  cheap  target  function.  Needs  more}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8322 \textcolor{comment}{     function evaluations that SQP (about  5x-\/10x  times  more),  but  its}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8323 \textcolor{comment}{     iterations  are  much  cheaper  that  that  of  SQP.  Activated  with}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8324 \textcolor{comment}{     minnlcsetalgoaul() function.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8325 \textcolor{comment}{   * SLP solver, successive linear programming. The slowest one,  requires}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8326 \textcolor{comment}{     more target function evaluations that SQP and  AUL.  However,  it  is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8327 \textcolor{comment}{     somewhat more robust in tricky cases, so it can be used  as  a backup}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8328 \textcolor{comment}{     plan. Activated with minnlcsetalgoslp() function.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8329 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8330 \textcolor{comment}{2. [optional] user activates OptGuard  integrity checker  which  tries  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8331 \textcolor{comment}{   detect possible errors in the user-\/supplied callbacks:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8332 \textcolor{comment}{   * discontinuity/nonsmoothness of the target/nonlinear constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8333 \textcolor{comment}{   * errors in the analytic gradient provided by user}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8334 \textcolor{comment}{   This feature is essential for early prototyping stages because it helps}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8335 \textcolor{comment}{   to catch common coding and problem statement errors.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8336 \textcolor{comment}{   OptGuard can be activated with following functions (one per each  check}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8337 \textcolor{comment}{   performed):}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8338 \textcolor{comment}{   * minnlcoptguardsmoothness()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8339 \textcolor{comment}{   * minnlcoptguardgradient()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8340 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8341 \textcolor{comment}{3. User adds boundary and/or linear and/or nonlinear constraints by  means}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8342 \textcolor{comment}{   of calling one of the following functions:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8343 \textcolor{comment}{   a) minnlcsetbc() for boundary constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8344 \textcolor{comment}{   b) minnlcsetlc() for linear constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8345 \textcolor{comment}{   c) minnlcsetnlc() for nonlinear constraints}}

\DoxyCodeLine{8392 \textcolor{comment}{This subroutine is a finite  difference variant of MinNLCCreate(). It uses}}

\DoxyCodeLine{8394 \textcolor{comment}{}}

\DoxyCodeLine{8408 \textcolor{comment}{    DiffStep-\/   differentiation step, >0}}

\DoxyCodeLine{8410 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8411 \textcolor{comment}{    State   -\/   structure stores algorithm state}}

\DoxyCodeLine{8413 \textcolor{comment}{NOTES:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8414 \textcolor{comment}{1. algorithm uses 4-\/point central formula for differentiation.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8415 \textcolor{comment}{2. differentiation step along I-\/th axis is equal to DiffStep*S[I] where}}

\DoxyCodeLine{8417 \textcolor{comment}{3. we recommend you to use moderate values of  differentiation  step.  Too}}

\DoxyCodeLine{8422 \textcolor{comment}{   calculation needs 4*N function evaluations. This function will work for}}

\DoxyCodeLine{8797 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8798 \textcolor{comment}{This  function  tells MinNLC unit to use  Augmented  Lagrangian  algorithm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8799 \textcolor{comment}{for nonlinearly constrained  optimization.  This  algorithm  is  a  slight}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8800 \textcolor{comment}{modification of one described in "{}A Modified Barrier-\/Augmented  Lagrangian}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8801 \textcolor{comment}{Method for  Constrained  Minimization  (1999)"{}  by  D.GOLDFARB,  R.POLYAK,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8802 \textcolor{comment}{K. SCHEINBERG, I.YUZEFOVICH.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8803 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8804 \textcolor{comment}{AUL solver can be significantly faster than SQP on easy  problems  due  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8805 \textcolor{comment}{cheaper iterations, although it needs more function evaluations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8806 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8807 \textcolor{comment}{Augmented Lagrangian algorithm works by converting problem  of  minimizing}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8808 \textcolor{comment}{F(x) subject to equality/inequality constraints   to unconstrained problem}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8809 \textcolor{comment}{of the form}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8810 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8811 \textcolor{comment}{    min[ f(x) +}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8812 \textcolor{comment}{        + Rho*PENALTY\_EQ(x)   + SHIFT\_EQ(x,Nu1) +}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8813 \textcolor{comment}{        + Rho*PENALTY\_INEQ(x) + SHIFT\_INEQ(x,Nu2) ]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8814 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8815 \textcolor{comment}{where:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8816 \textcolor{comment}{* Rho is a fixed penalization coefficient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8817 \textcolor{comment}{* PENALTY\_EQ(x) is a penalty term, which is used to APPROXIMATELY  enforce}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8818 \textcolor{comment}{  equality constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8819 \textcolor{comment}{* SHIFT\_EQ(x) is a special "{}shift"{}  term  which  is  used  to  "{}fine-\/tune"{}}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8820 \textcolor{comment}{  equality constraints, greatly increasing precision}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8821 \textcolor{comment}{* PENALTY\_INEQ(x) is a penalty term which is used to approximately enforce}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8822 \textcolor{comment}{  inequality constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8823 \textcolor{comment}{* SHIFT\_INEQ(x) is a special "{}shift"{}  term  which  is  used to "{}fine-\/tune"{}}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8824 \textcolor{comment}{  inequality constraints, greatly increasing precision}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8825 \textcolor{comment}{* Nu1/Nu2 are vectors of Lagrange coefficients which are fine-\/tuned during}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8826 \textcolor{comment}{  outer iterations of algorithm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8827 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8828 \textcolor{comment}{This  version  of  AUL  algorithm  uses   preconditioner,  which   greatly}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8829 \textcolor{comment}{accelerates convergence. Because this  algorithm  is  similar  to  penalty}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8830 \textcolor{comment}{methods,  it  may  perform  steps  into  infeasible  area.  All  kinds  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8831 \textcolor{comment}{constraints (boundary, linear and nonlinear ones) may   be   violated   in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8832 \textcolor{comment}{intermediate points -\/ and in the solution.  However,  properly  configured}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8833 \textcolor{comment}{AUL method is significantly better at handling  constraints  than  barrier}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8834 \textcolor{comment}{and/or penalty methods.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8835 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8836 \textcolor{comment}{The very basic outline of algorithm is given below:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8837 \textcolor{comment}{1) first outer iteration is performed with "{}default"{}  values  of  Lagrange}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8838 \textcolor{comment}{   multipliers Nu1/Nu2. Solution quality is low (candidate  point  can  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8839 \textcolor{comment}{   too  far  away  from  true  solution; large violation of constraints is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8840 \textcolor{comment}{   possible) and is comparable with that of penalty methods.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8841 \textcolor{comment}{2) subsequent outer iterations  refine  Lagrange  multipliers  and improve}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8842 \textcolor{comment}{   quality of the solution.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8843 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8844 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8845 \textcolor{comment}{    State   -\/   structure which stores algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8846 \textcolor{comment}{    Rho     -\/   penalty coefficient, Rho>0:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8847 \textcolor{comment}{                * large enough  that  algorithm  converges  with   desired}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8848 \textcolor{comment}{                  precision. Minimum value is 10*max(S'*diag(H)*S),  where}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8849 \textcolor{comment}{                  S is a scale matrix (set by MinNLCSetScale) and H  is  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8850 \textcolor{comment}{                  Hessian of the function being minimized. If you can  not}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8851 \textcolor{comment}{                  easily estimate Hessian norm,  see  our  recommendations}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8852 \textcolor{comment}{                  below.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8853 \textcolor{comment}{                * not TOO large to prevent ill-\/conditioning}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8854 \textcolor{comment}{                * for unit-\/scale problems (variables and Hessian have unit}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8855 \textcolor{comment}{                  magnitude), Rho=100 or Rho=1000 can be used.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8856 \textcolor{comment}{                * it is important to note that Rho is internally multiplied}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8857 \textcolor{comment}{                  by scaling matrix, i.e. optimum value of Rho depends  on}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8858 \textcolor{comment}{                  scale of variables specified  by  MinNLCSetScale().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8859 \textcolor{comment}{    ItsCnt  -\/   number of outer iterations:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8860 \textcolor{comment}{                * ItsCnt=0 means that small number of outer iterations  is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8861 \textcolor{comment}{                  automatically chosen (10 iterations in current version).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8862 \textcolor{comment}{                * ItsCnt=1 means that AUL algorithm performs just as usual}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8863 \textcolor{comment}{                  barrier method.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8864 \textcolor{comment}{                * ItsCnt>1 means that  AUL  algorithm  performs  specified}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8865 \textcolor{comment}{                  number of outer iterations}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8866 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8867 \textcolor{comment}{HOW TO CHOOSE PARAMETERS}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8868 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8869 \textcolor{comment}{Nonlinear optimization is a tricky area and Augmented Lagrangian algorithm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8870 \textcolor{comment}{is sometimes hard to tune. Good values of  Rho  and  ItsCnt  are  problem-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8871 \textcolor{comment}{specific.  In  order  to  help  you   we   prepared   following   set   of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8872 \textcolor{comment}{recommendations:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8873 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8874 \textcolor{comment}{* for  unit-\/scale  problems  (variables  and Hessian have unit magnitude),}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8875 \textcolor{comment}{  Rho=100 or Rho=1000 can be used.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8876 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8877 \textcolor{comment}{* start from  some  small  value of Rho and solve problem  with  just  one}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8878 \textcolor{comment}{  outer iteration (ItcCnt=1). In this case algorithm behaves like  penalty}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8879 \textcolor{comment}{  method. Increase Rho in 2x or 10x steps until you  see  that  one  outer}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8880 \textcolor{comment}{  iteration returns point which is "{}rough approximation to solution"{}.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8881 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8882 \textcolor{comment}{  It is very important to have Rho so  large  that  penalty  term  becomes}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8883 \textcolor{comment}{  constraining i.e. modified function becomes highly convex in constrained}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8884 \textcolor{comment}{  directions.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8885 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8886 \textcolor{comment}{  From the other side, too large Rho may prevent you  from  converging  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8887 \textcolor{comment}{  the solution. You can diagnose it by studying number of inner iterations}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8888 \textcolor{comment}{  performed by algorithm: too few (5-\/10 on  1000-\/dimensional  problem)  or}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8889 \textcolor{comment}{  too many (orders of magnitude more than  dimensionality)  usually  means}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8890 \textcolor{comment}{  that Rho is too large.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8891 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8892 \textcolor{comment}{* with just one outer iteration you  usually  have  low-\/quality  solution.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8893 \textcolor{comment}{  Some constraints can be violated with very  large  margin,  while  other}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8894 \textcolor{comment}{  ones (which are NOT violated in the true solution) can push final  point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8895 \textcolor{comment}{  too far in the inner area of the feasible set.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8896 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8897 \textcolor{comment}{  For example, if you have constraint x0>=0 and true solution  x0=1,  then}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8898 \textcolor{comment}{  merely a presence of "{}x0>=0"{} will introduce a bias towards larger values}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8899 \textcolor{comment}{  of x0. Say, algorithm may stop at x0=1.5 instead of 1.0.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8900 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8901 \textcolor{comment}{* after you found good Rho, you may increase number of  outer  iterations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8902 \textcolor{comment}{  ItsCnt=10 is a good value. Subsequent outer iteration will refine values}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8903 \textcolor{comment}{  of  Lagrange  multipliers.  Constraints  which  were  violated  will  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8904 \textcolor{comment}{  enforced, inactive constraints will be dropped (corresponding multipliers}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8905 \textcolor{comment}{  will be decreased). Ideally, you  should  see  10-\/1000x  improvement  in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8906 \textcolor{comment}{  constraint handling (constraint violation is reduced).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8907 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8908 \textcolor{comment}{* if  you  see  that  algorithm  converges  to  vicinity  of solution, but}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8909 \textcolor{comment}{  additional outer iterations do not refine solution,  it  may  mean  that}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8910 \textcolor{comment}{  algorithm is unstable -\/ it wanders around true  solution,  but  can  not}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8911 \textcolor{comment}{  approach it. Sometimes algorithm may be stabilized by increasing Rho one}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8912 \textcolor{comment}{  more time, making it 5x or 10x larger.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8913 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8914 \textcolor{comment}{SCALING OF CONSTRAINTS [IMPORTANT]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8915 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8916 \textcolor{comment}{AUL optimizer scales   variables   according   to   scale   specified   by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8917 \textcolor{comment}{MinNLCSetScale() function, so it can handle  problems  with  badly  scaled}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8918 \textcolor{comment}{variables (as long as we KNOW their scales).   However,  because  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8919 \textcolor{comment}{being optimized is a mix  of  original  function and  constraint-\/dependent}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8920 \textcolor{comment}{penalty  functions, it  is   important  to   rescale  both  variables  AND}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8921 \textcolor{comment}{constraints.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8922 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8923 \textcolor{comment}{Say,  if  you  minimize f(x)=x\string^2 subject to 1000000*x>=0,  then  you  have}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8924 \textcolor{comment}{constraint whose scale is different from that of target  function (another}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8925 \textcolor{comment}{example is 0.000001*x>=0). It is also possible to have constraints   whose}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8926 \textcolor{comment}{scales  are   misaligned:   1000000*x0>=0, 0.000001*x1<=0.   Inappropriate}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8927 \textcolor{comment}{scaling may ruin convergence because minimizing x\string^2 subject to x>=0 is NOT}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8928 \textcolor{comment}{same as minimizing it subject to 1000000*x>=0.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8929 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8930 \textcolor{comment}{Because we  know  coefficients  of  boundary/linear  constraints,  we  can}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8931 \textcolor{comment}{automatically rescale and normalize them. However,  there  is  no  way  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8932 \textcolor{comment}{automatically rescale nonlinear constraints Gi(x) and  Hi(x)  -\/  they  are}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8933 \textcolor{comment}{black boxes.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8934 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8935 \textcolor{comment}{It means that YOU are the one who is  responsible  for  correct scaling of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8936 \textcolor{comment}{nonlinear constraints  Gi(x)  and  Hi(x).  We  recommend  you  to  rescale}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8937 \textcolor{comment}{nonlinear constraints in such way that I-\/th component of dG/dX (or  dH/dx)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8938 \textcolor{comment}{has magnitude approximately equal to 1/S[i] (where S  is  a  scale  set by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8939 \textcolor{comment}{MinNLCSetScale() function).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8940 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8941 \textcolor{comment}{WHAT IF IT DOES NOT CONVERGE?}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8942 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8943 \textcolor{comment}{It is possible that AUL algorithm fails to converge to precise  values  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8944 \textcolor{comment}{Lagrange multipliers. It stops somewhere around true solution, but candidate}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8945 \textcolor{comment}{point is still too far from solution, and some constraints  are  violated.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8946 \textcolor{comment}{Such kind of failure is specific for Lagrangian algorithms -\/  technically,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8947 \textcolor{comment}{they stop at some point, but this point is not constrained solution.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8948 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8949 \textcolor{comment}{There are exist several reasons why algorithm may fail to converge:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8950 \textcolor{comment}{a) too loose stopping criteria for inner iteration}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8951 \textcolor{comment}{b) degenerate, redundant constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8952 \textcolor{comment}{c) target function has unconstrained extremum exactly at the  boundary  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8953 \textcolor{comment}{   some constraint}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8954 \textcolor{comment}{d) numerical noise in the target function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8955 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8956 \textcolor{comment}{In all these cases algorithm is unstable -\/ each outer iteration results in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8957 \textcolor{comment}{large and almost random step which improves handling of some  constraints,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8958 \textcolor{comment}{but violates other ones (ideally  outer iterations should form a  sequence}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8959 \textcolor{comment}{of progressively decreasing steps towards solution).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8960 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8961 \textcolor{comment}{First reason possible is  that  too  loose  stopping  criteria  for  inner}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8962 \textcolor{comment}{iteration were specified. Augmented Lagrangian algorithm solves a sequence}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8963 \textcolor{comment}{of intermediate problems, and requries each of them to be solved with high}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8964 \textcolor{comment}{precision. Insufficient precision results in incorrect update of  Lagrange}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8965 \textcolor{comment}{multipliers.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8966 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8967 \textcolor{comment}{Another reason is that you may have specified degenerate constraints: say,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8968 \textcolor{comment}{some constraint was repeated twice. In most cases AUL algorithm gracefully}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8969 \textcolor{comment}{handles such situations, but sometimes it may spend too much time figuring}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8970 \textcolor{comment}{out subtle degeneracies in constraint matrix.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8971 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8972 \textcolor{comment}{Third reason is tricky and hard to diagnose. Consider situation  when  you}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8973 \textcolor{comment}{minimize  f=x\string^2  subject to constraint x>=0.  Unconstrained   extremum  is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8974 \textcolor{comment}{located  exactly  at  the  boundary  of  constrained  area.  In  this case}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8975 \textcolor{comment}{algorithm will tend to oscillate between negative  and  positive  x.  Each}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8976 \textcolor{comment}{time it stops at x<0 it "{}reinforces"{} constraint x>=0, and each time it  is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8977 \textcolor{comment}{bounced to x>0 it "{}relaxes"{} constraint (and is  attracted  to  x<0).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8978 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8979 \textcolor{comment}{Such situation  sometimes  happens  in  problems  with  hidden  symetries.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8980 \textcolor{comment}{Algorithm  is  got  caught  in  a  loop with  Lagrange  multipliers  being}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8981 \textcolor{comment}{continuously increased/decreased. Luckily, such loop forms after at  least}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8982 \textcolor{comment}{three iterations, so this problem can be solved by  DECREASING  number  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8983 \textcolor{comment}{outer iterations down to 1-\/2 and increasing  penalty  coefficient  Rho  as}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8984 \textcolor{comment}{much as possible.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8985 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8986 \textcolor{comment}{Final reason is numerical noise. AUL algorithm is robust against  moderate}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8987 \textcolor{comment}{noise (more robust than, say, active set methods),  but  large  noise  may}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8988 \textcolor{comment}{destabilize algorithm.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8989 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8990 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8991 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 06.06.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8992 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8993 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} minnlcsetalgoaul(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1minnlcstate}{minnlcstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \textcolor{keywordtype}{double} rho, \textcolor{keyword}{const} ae\_int\_t itscnt, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
\DoxyCodeLine{8994 }
\DoxyCodeLine{8995 }
\DoxyCodeLine{8996 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8997 \textcolor{comment}{This   function  tells  MinNLC  optimizer  to  use  SLP (Successive Linear}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8998 \textcolor{comment}{Programming) algorithm for  nonlinearly  constrained   optimization.  This}}
\DoxyCodeLine{8999 \textcolor{comment}{algorithm  is  a  slight  modification  of  one  described  in  "{}A  Linear}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9000 \textcolor{comment}{programming-\/based optimization algorithm for solving nonlinear programming}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9001 \textcolor{comment}{problems"{} (2010) by Claus Still and Tapio Westerlund.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9002 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9003 \textcolor{comment}{This solver is the slowest one in ALGLIB, it requires more target function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9004 \textcolor{comment}{evaluations that SQP and AUL. However it is somewhat more robust in tricky}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9005 \textcolor{comment}{cases, so it can be used as a backup plan. We recommend to use  this  algo}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9006 \textcolor{comment}{when SQP/AUL do not work (does not return  the  solution  you  expect). If}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9007 \textcolor{comment}{trying different approach gives same  results,  then  MAYBE  something  is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9008 \textcolor{comment}{wrong with your optimization problem.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9009 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9010 \textcolor{comment}{Despite its name ("{}linear"{} = "{}first order method"{}) this algorithm performs}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9011 \textcolor{comment}{steps similar to that of conjugate gradients method;  internally  it  uses}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9012 \textcolor{comment}{orthogonality/conjugacy requirement for subsequent steps  which  makes  it}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9013 \textcolor{comment}{closer to second order methods in terms of convergence speed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9014 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9015 \textcolor{comment}{Convergence is proved for the following case:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9016 \textcolor{comment}{* function and constraints are continuously differentiable (C1 class)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9017 \textcolor{comment}{* extended MangasarianFromovitz constraint qualification  (EMFCQ)  holds;}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9018 \textcolor{comment}{  in the context of this algorithm EMFCQ  means  that  one  can,  for  any}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9019 \textcolor{comment}{  infeasible  point,  find  a  search  direction  such that the constraint}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9020 \textcolor{comment}{  infeasibilities are reduced.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9021 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9022 \textcolor{comment}{This algorithm has following nice properties:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9023 \textcolor{comment}{* no parameters to tune}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9024 \textcolor{comment}{* no convexity requirements for target function or constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9025 \textcolor{comment}{* initial point can be infeasible}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9026 \textcolor{comment}{* algorithm respects box constraints in all intermediate points  (it  does}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9027 \textcolor{comment}{  not even evaluate function outside of box constrained area)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9028 \textcolor{comment}{* once linear constraints are enforced, algorithm will not violate them}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9029 \textcolor{comment}{* no such guarantees can be provided for nonlinear constraints,  but  once}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9030 \textcolor{comment}{  nonlinear constraints are enforced, algorithm will try  to  respect them}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9031 \textcolor{comment}{  as much as possible}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9032 \textcolor{comment}{* numerical differentiation does not  violate  box  constraints  (although}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9033 \textcolor{comment}{  general linear and nonlinear ones can be violated during differentiation)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9034 \textcolor{comment}{* from our experience, this algorithm is somewhat more  robust  in  really}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9035 \textcolor{comment}{  difficult cases}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9036 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9037 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9038 \textcolor{comment}{    State   -\/   structure which stores algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9039 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9040 \textcolor{comment}{===== TRACING SLP SOLVER =================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9041 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9042 \textcolor{comment}{SLP solver supports advanced tracing capabilities. You can trace algorithm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9043 \textcolor{comment}{output by specifying following trace symbols (case-\/insensitive)  by  means}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9044 \textcolor{comment}{of trace\_file() call:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9045 \textcolor{comment}{* 'SLP'         -\/ for basic trace of algorithm  steps and decisions.  Only}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9046 \textcolor{comment}{                  short scalars (function values and deltas) are  printed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9047 \textcolor{comment}{                  N-\/dimensional quantities like search directions are  NOT}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9048 \textcolor{comment}{                  printed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9049 \textcolor{comment}{                  It also prints OptGuard  integrity  checker  report when}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9050 \textcolor{comment}{                  nonsmoothness of target/constraints is suspected.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9051 \textcolor{comment}{* 'SLP.DETAILED'-\/ for output of points being visited and search directions}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9052 \textcolor{comment}{                  This  symbol  also  implicitly  defines  'SLP'. You  can}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9053 \textcolor{comment}{                  control output format by additionally specifying:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9054 \textcolor{comment}{                  * nothing     to output in  6-\/digit exponential format}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9055 \textcolor{comment}{                  * 'PREC.E15'  to output in 15-\/digit exponential format}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9056 \textcolor{comment}{                  * 'PREC.F6'   to output in  6-\/digit fixed-\/point format}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9057 \textcolor{comment}{* 'SLP.PROBING' -\/ to let algorithm insert additional function  evaluations}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9058 \textcolor{comment}{                  before line search  in  order  to  build  human-\/readable}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9059 \textcolor{comment}{                  chart of the raw  Lagrangian  (\string~40  additional  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9060 \textcolor{comment}{                  evaluations is performed for  each  line  search).  This}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9061 \textcolor{comment}{                  symbol also implicitly defines 'SLP'. Definition of this}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9062 \textcolor{comment}{                  symbol also automatically activates OptGuard  smoothness}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9063 \textcolor{comment}{                  monitor.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9064 \textcolor{comment}{* 'OPTGUARD'    -\/ for report of smoothness/continuity violations in target}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9065 \textcolor{comment}{                  and/or constraints. This kind of reporting is   included}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9066 \textcolor{comment}{                  in 'SLP', but it comes with lots of additional info.  If}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9067 \textcolor{comment}{                  you  need  just  smoothness  monitoring,   specify  this}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9068 \textcolor{comment}{                  setting.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9069 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9070 \textcolor{comment}{                  NOTE: this tag merely directs  OptGuard  output  to  log}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9071 \textcolor{comment}{                        file. Even if you specify it, you  still  have  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9072 \textcolor{comment}{                        configure OptGuard  by calling minnlcoptguard...()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9073 \textcolor{comment}{                        family of functions.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9074 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9075 \textcolor{comment}{By default trace is disabled and adds  no  overhead  to  the  optimization}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9076 \textcolor{comment}{process. However, specifying any of the symbols adds some  formatting  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9077 \textcolor{comment}{output-\/related   overhead.  Specifying  'SLP.PROBING'  adds   even  larger}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9078 \textcolor{comment}{overhead due to additional function evaluations being performed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9079 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9080 \textcolor{comment}{You may specify multiple symbols by separating them with commas:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9081 \textcolor{comment}{>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9082 \textcolor{comment}{> alglib::trace\_file("{}SLP,SLP.PROBING,PREC.F6"{}, "{}path/to/trace.log"{})}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9083 \textcolor{comment}{>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9084 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9085 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9086 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 02.04.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9087 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9088 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} minnlcsetalgoslp(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1minnlcstate}{minnlcstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
\DoxyCodeLine{9089 }
\DoxyCodeLine{9090 }
\DoxyCodeLine{9091 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9092 \textcolor{comment}{This   function  tells  MinNLC  optimizer to use SQP (Successive Quadratic}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9093 \textcolor{comment}{Programming) algorithm for nonlinearly constrained optimization.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9094 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9095 \textcolor{comment}{This algorithm needs order of magnitude (5x-\/10x) less function evaluations}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9096 \textcolor{comment}{than AUL solver, but has higher overhead because each  iteration  involves}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9097 \textcolor{comment}{solution of quadratic programming problem.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9098 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9099 \textcolor{comment}{Convergence is proved for the following case:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9100 \textcolor{comment}{* function and constraints are continuously differentiable (C1 class)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9101 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9102 \textcolor{comment}{This algorithm has following nice properties:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9103 \textcolor{comment}{* no parameters to tune}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9104 \textcolor{comment}{* no convexity requirements for target function or constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9105 \textcolor{comment}{* initial point can be infeasible}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9106 \textcolor{comment}{* algorithm respects box constraints in all intermediate points  (it  does}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9107 \textcolor{comment}{  not even evaluate function outside of box constrained area)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9108 \textcolor{comment}{* once linear constraints are enforced, algorithm will not violate them}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9109 \textcolor{comment}{* no such guarantees can be provided for nonlinear constraints,  but  once}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9110 \textcolor{comment}{  nonlinear constraints are enforced, algorithm will try  to  respect them}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9111 \textcolor{comment}{  as much as possible}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9112 \textcolor{comment}{* numerical differentiation does not  violate  box  constraints  (although}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9113 \textcolor{comment}{  general linear and nonlinear ones can be violated during differentiation)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9114 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9115 \textcolor{comment}{We recommend this algorithm as a default option for medium-\/scale  problems}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9116 \textcolor{comment}{(less than thousand of variables) or problems with target  function  being}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9117 \textcolor{comment}{hard to evaluate.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9118 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9119 \textcolor{comment}{For   large-\/scale  problems  or  ones  with very  cheap  target   function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9120 \textcolor{comment}{AUL solver can be better option.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9121 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9122 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9123 \textcolor{comment}{    State   -\/   structure which stores algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9124 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9125 \textcolor{comment}{===== INTERACTION WITH OPTGUARD ==========================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9126 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9127 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard integrity  checker  allows us to catch problems  like  errors  in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9128 \textcolor{comment}{gradients   and  discontinuity/nonsmoothness  of  the  target/constraints.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9129 \textcolor{comment}{The latter kind of problems can be detected  by looking upon line searches}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9130 \textcolor{comment}{performed during optimization and searching for signs of nonsmoothness.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9131 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9132 \textcolor{comment}{The problem with SQP is that it is too good for OptGuard to work -\/ it does}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9133 \textcolor{comment}{not perform line searches. It typically  needs  1-\/2  function  evaluations}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9134 \textcolor{comment}{per step, and it is not enough for OptGuard to detect nonsmoothness.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9135 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9136 \textcolor{comment}{So, if you suspect that your problem is  nonsmooth  and  if  you  want  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9137 \textcolor{comment}{confirm or deny it, we recommend you to either:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9138 \textcolor{comment}{* use AUL or SLP solvers, which can detect nonsmoothness of the problem}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9139 \textcolor{comment}{* or, alternatively, activate 'SQP.PROBING' trace  tag  that  will  insert}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9140 \textcolor{comment}{  additional  function  evaluations (\string~40  per  line  step) that will  help}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9141 \textcolor{comment}{  OptGuard integrity checker to study properties of your problem}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9142 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9143 \textcolor{comment}{===== TRACING SQP SOLVER =================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9144 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9145 \textcolor{comment}{SQP solver supports advanced tracing capabilities. You can trace algorithm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9146 \textcolor{comment}{output by specifying following trace symbols (case-\/insensitive)  by  means}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9147 \textcolor{comment}{of trace\_file() call:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9148 \textcolor{comment}{* 'SQP'         -\/ for basic trace of algorithm  steps and decisions.  Only}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9149 \textcolor{comment}{                  short scalars (function values and deltas) are  printed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9150 \textcolor{comment}{                  N-\/dimensional quantities like search directions are  NOT}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9151 \textcolor{comment}{                  printed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9152 \textcolor{comment}{                  It also prints OptGuard  integrity  checker  report when}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9153 \textcolor{comment}{                  nonsmoothness of target/constraints is suspected.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9154 \textcolor{comment}{* 'SQP.DETAILED'-\/ for output of points being visited and search directions}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9155 \textcolor{comment}{                  This  symbol  also  implicitly  defines  'SQP'. You  can}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9156 \textcolor{comment}{                  control output format by additionally specifying:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9157 \textcolor{comment}{                  * nothing     to output in  6-\/digit exponential format}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9158 \textcolor{comment}{                  * 'PREC.E15'  to output in 15-\/digit exponential format}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9159 \textcolor{comment}{                  * 'PREC.F6'   to output in  6-\/digit fixed-\/point format}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9160 \textcolor{comment}{* 'SQP.PROBING' -\/ to let algorithm insert additional function  evaluations}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9161 \textcolor{comment}{                  before line search  in  order  to  build  human-\/readable}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9162 \textcolor{comment}{                  chart of the raw  Lagrangian  (\string~40  additional  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9163 \textcolor{comment}{                  evaluations is performed for  each  line  search).  This}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9164 \textcolor{comment}{                  symbol  also  implicitly  defines  'SQP'  and  activates}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9165 \textcolor{comment}{                  OptGuard integrity checker which detects continuity  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9166 \textcolor{comment}{                  smoothness violations. An OptGuard log is printed at the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9167 \textcolor{comment}{                  end of the file.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9168 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9169 \textcolor{comment}{By default trace is disabled and adds  no  overhead  to  the  optimization}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9170 \textcolor{comment}{process. However, specifying any of the symbols adds some  formatting  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9171 \textcolor{comment}{output-\/related   overhead.  Specifying  'SQP.PROBING'  adds   even  larger}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9172 \textcolor{comment}{overhead due to additional function evaluations being performed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9173 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9174 \textcolor{comment}{You may specify multiple symbols by separating them with commas:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9175 \textcolor{comment}{>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9176 \textcolor{comment}{> alglib::trace\_file("{}SQP,SQP.PROBING,PREC.F6"{}, "{}path/to/trace.log"{})}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9177 \textcolor{comment}{>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9178 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9179 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9180 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 02.12.2019 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9181 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9215 \textcolor{comment}{This family of functions is used to launcn iterations of nonlinear optimizer}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9216 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9217 \textcolor{comment}{These functions accept following parameters:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9218 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9219 \textcolor{comment}{    fvec    -\/   callback which calculates function vector fi[]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9220 \textcolor{comment}{                at given point x}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9221 \textcolor{comment}{    jac     -\/   callback which calculates function vector fi[]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9222 \textcolor{comment}{                and Jacobian jac at given point x}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9223 \textcolor{comment}{    rep     -\/   optional callback which is called after each iteration}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9224 \textcolor{comment}{                can be NULL}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9225 \textcolor{comment}{    ptr     -\/   optional pointer which is passed to func/grad/hess/jac/rep}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9226 \textcolor{comment}{                can be NULL}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9227 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9228 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9229 \textcolor{comment}{NOTES:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9230 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9231 \textcolor{comment}{1. This function has two different implementations: one which  uses  exact}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9232 \textcolor{comment}{   (analytical) user-\/supplied Jacobian, and one which uses  only  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9233 \textcolor{comment}{   vector and numerically  differentiates  function  in  order  to  obtain}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9234 \textcolor{comment}{   gradient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9235 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9236 \textcolor{comment}{   Depending  on  the  specific  function  used to create optimizer object}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9238 \textcolor{comment}{   accepts function AND Jacobian or one which accepts ONLY function.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9239 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9240 \textcolor{comment}{   Be careful to choose variant of MinNLCOptimize()  which  corresponds to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9241 \textcolor{comment}{   your optimization scheme! Table below lists different  combinations  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9242 \textcolor{comment}{   callback (function/gradient) passed to MinNLCOptimize()   and  specific}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9243 \textcolor{comment}{   function used to create optimizer.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9244 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9245 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9246 \textcolor{comment}{                     |         USER PASSED TO MinNLCOptimize()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9247 \textcolor{comment}{   CREATED WITH      |  function only   |  function and gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9248 \textcolor{comment}{   -\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9249 \textcolor{comment}{   MinNLCCreateF()   |     works               FAILS}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9250 \textcolor{comment}{   MinNLCCreate()    |     FAILS               works}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9251 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9252 \textcolor{comment}{   Here "{}FAILS"{} denotes inappropriate combinations  of  optimizer creation}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9253 \textcolor{comment}{   function  and  MinNLCOptimize()  version.   Attemps   to    use    such}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9254 \textcolor{comment}{   combination will lead to exception. Either  you  did  not pass gradient}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9257 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9273 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9274 \textcolor{comment}{This  function  activates/deactivates verification  of  the  user-\/supplied}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9275 \textcolor{comment}{analytic gradient/Jacobian.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9276 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9277 \textcolor{comment}{Upon  activation  of  this  option  OptGuard  integrity  checker  performs}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9278 \textcolor{comment}{numerical differentiation of your target  function  (constraints)  at  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9279 \textcolor{comment}{initial point (note: future versions may also perform check  at  the final}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9280 \textcolor{comment}{point) and compares numerical gradient/Jacobian with analytic one provided}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9281 \textcolor{comment}{by you.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9282 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9283 \textcolor{comment}{If difference is too large, an error flag is set and optimization  session}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9284 \textcolor{comment}{continues. After optimization session is over, you can retrieve the report}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9285 \textcolor{comment}{which stores both gradients/Jacobians, and specific components highlighted}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9286 \textcolor{comment}{as suspicious by the OptGuard.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9287 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9288 \textcolor{comment}{The primary OptGuard report can be retrieved with minnlcoptguardresults().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9289 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9290 \textcolor{comment}{IMPORTANT: gradient check is a high-\/overhead option which  will  cost  you}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9291 \textcolor{comment}{           about 3*N additional function evaluations. In many cases it may}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9292 \textcolor{comment}{           cost as much as the rest of the optimization session.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9293 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9294 \textcolor{comment}{           YOU SHOULD NOT USE IT IN THE PRODUCTION CODE UNLESS YOU WANT TO}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9295 \textcolor{comment}{           CHECK DERIVATIVES PROVIDED BY SOME THIRD PARTY.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9296 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9297 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: unlike previous incarnation of the gradient checking code,  OptGuard}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9298 \textcolor{comment}{      does NOT interrupt optimization even if it discovers bad gradient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9299 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9300 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9301 \textcolor{comment}{    State       -\/   structure used to store algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9302 \textcolor{comment}{    TestStep    -\/   verification step used for numerical differentiation:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9303 \textcolor{comment}{                    * TestStep=0 turns verification off}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9304 \textcolor{comment}{                    * TestStep>0 activates verification}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9305 \textcolor{comment}{                    You should carefully choose TestStep. Value  which  is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9306 \textcolor{comment}{                    too large (so large that  function  behavior  is  non-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9307 \textcolor{comment}{                    cubic at this scale) will lead  to  false  alarms. Too}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9308 \textcolor{comment}{                    short step will result in rounding  errors  dominating}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9309 \textcolor{comment}{                    numerical derivative.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9310 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9311 \textcolor{comment}{                    You may use different step for different parameters by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9312 \textcolor{comment}{                    means of setting scale with minnlcsetscale().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9313 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9314 \textcolor{comment}{=== EXPLANATION ==========================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9315 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9316 \textcolor{comment}{In order to verify gradient algorithm performs following steps:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9317 \textcolor{comment}{  * two trial steps are made to X[i]-\/TestStep*S[i] and X[i]+TestStep*S[i],}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9318 \textcolor{comment}{    where X[i] is i-\/th component of the initial point and S[i] is a  scale}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9319 \textcolor{comment}{    of i-\/th parameter}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9320 \textcolor{comment}{  * F(X) is evaluated at these trial points}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9321 \textcolor{comment}{  * we perform one more evaluation in the middle point of the interval}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9322 \textcolor{comment}{  * we  build  cubic  model using function values and derivatives at trial}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9323 \textcolor{comment}{    points and we compare its prediction with actual value in  the  middle}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9324 \textcolor{comment}{    point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9325 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9326 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9327 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 15.06.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9328 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9329 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} minnlcoptguardgradient(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1minnlcstate}{minnlcstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \textcolor{keywordtype}{double} teststep, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
\DoxyCodeLine{9330 }
\DoxyCodeLine{9331 }
\DoxyCodeLine{9332 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9333 \textcolor{comment}{This  function  activates/deactivates nonsmoothness monitoring  option  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9334 \textcolor{comment}{the  OptGuard  integrity  checker. Smoothness  monitor  silently  observes}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9335 \textcolor{comment}{solution process and tries to detect ill-\/posed problems, i.e. ones with:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9336 \textcolor{comment}{a) discontinuous target function (non-\/C0) and/or constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9337 \textcolor{comment}{b) nonsmooth     target function (non-\/C1) and/or constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9338 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9339 \textcolor{comment}{Smoothness monitoring does NOT interrupt optimization  even if it suspects}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9340 \textcolor{comment}{that your problem is nonsmooth. It just sets corresponding  flags  in  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9341 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard report which can be retrieved after optimization is over.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9342 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9343 \textcolor{comment}{Smoothness monitoring is a moderate overhead option which often adds  less}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9344 \textcolor{comment}{than 1\% to the optimizer running time. Thus, you can use it even for large}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9345 \textcolor{comment}{scale problems.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9346 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9347 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: OptGuard does  NOT  guarantee  that  it  will  always  detect  C0/C1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9348 \textcolor{comment}{      continuity violations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9349 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9350 \textcolor{comment}{      First, minor errors are hard to  catch -\/ say, a 0.0001 difference in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9351 \textcolor{comment}{      the model values at two sides of the gap may be due to discontinuity}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9352 \textcolor{comment}{      of the model -\/ or simply because the model has changed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9353 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9354 \textcolor{comment}{      Second, C1-\/violations  are  especially  difficult  to  detect  in  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9355 \textcolor{comment}{      noninvasive way. The optimizer usually  performs  very  short  steps}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9356 \textcolor{comment}{      near the nonsmoothness, and differentiation  usually   introduces  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9357 \textcolor{comment}{      lot of numerical noise.  It  is  hard  to  tell  whether  some  tiny}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9358 \textcolor{comment}{      discontinuity in the slope is due to real nonsmoothness or just  due}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9359 \textcolor{comment}{      to numerical noise alone.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9360 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9361 \textcolor{comment}{      Our top priority was to avoid false positives, so in some rare cases}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9362 \textcolor{comment}{      minor errors may went unnoticed (however, in most cases they can  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9363 \textcolor{comment}{      spotted with restart from different initial point).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9364 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9365 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9366 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9367 \textcolor{comment}{    level   -\/   monitoring level:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9368 \textcolor{comment}{                * 0 -\/ monitoring is disabled}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9369 \textcolor{comment}{                * 1 -\/ noninvasive low-\/overhead monitoring; function values}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9370 \textcolor{comment}{                      and/or gradients are recorded, but OptGuard does not}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9371 \textcolor{comment}{                      try to perform additional evaluations  in  order  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9372 \textcolor{comment}{                      get more information about suspicious locations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9373 \textcolor{comment}{                      This kind of monitoring does not work well with  SQP}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9374 \textcolor{comment}{                      because SQP solver needs just 1-\/2 function evaluations}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9375 \textcolor{comment}{                      per step, which is not enough for OptGuard  to  make}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9376 \textcolor{comment}{                      any conclusions.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9377 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9378 \textcolor{comment}{=== EXPLANATION ==========================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9379 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9380 \textcolor{comment}{One major source of headache during optimization  is  the  possibility  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9381 \textcolor{comment}{the coding errors in the target function/constraints (or their gradients).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9382 \textcolor{comment}{Such  errors   most   often   manifest   themselves  as  discontinuity  or}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9383 \textcolor{comment}{nonsmoothness of the target/constraints.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9384 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9385 \textcolor{comment}{Another frequent situation is when you try to optimize something involving}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9386 \textcolor{comment}{lots of min() and max() operations, i.e. nonsmooth target. Although not  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9387 \textcolor{comment}{coding error, it is nonsmoothness anyway -\/ and smooth  optimizers  usually}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9388 \textcolor{comment}{stop right after encountering nonsmoothness, well before reaching solution.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9389 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9390 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard integrity checker helps you to catch such situations: it monitors}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9391 \textcolor{comment}{function values/gradients being passed  to  the  optimizer  and  tries  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9392 \textcolor{comment}{errors. Upon discovering suspicious pair of points it  raises  appropriate}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9393 \textcolor{comment}{flag (and allows you to continue optimization). When optimization is done,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9394 \textcolor{comment}{you can study OptGuard result.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9395 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9396 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9397 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 21.11.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9398 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9399 \textcolor{keywordtype}{void} minnlcoptguardsmoothness(\textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{classalglib_1_1minnlcstate}{minnlcstate}} \&state, \textcolor{keyword}{const} ae\_int\_t level, \textcolor{keyword}{const} \mbox{\hyperlink{structalglib_1_1xparams}{xparams}} \_xparams = alglib::xdefault);}
