\DoxyCodeLine{9403 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9404 \textcolor{comment}{Results of OptGuard integrity check, should be called  after  optimization}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9405 \textcolor{comment}{session is over.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9406 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9407 \textcolor{comment}{=== PRIMARY REPORT =======================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9408 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9409 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard performs several checks which are intended to catch common errors}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9410 \textcolor{comment}{in the implementation of nonlinear function/gradient:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9411 \textcolor{comment}{* incorrect analytic gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9412 \textcolor{comment}{* discontinuous (non-\/C0) target functions (constraints)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9413 \textcolor{comment}{* nonsmooth     (non-\/C1) target functions (constraints)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9414 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9415 \textcolor{comment}{Each of these checks is activated with appropriate function:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9416 \textcolor{comment}{* minnlcoptguardgradient() for gradient verification}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9417 \textcolor{comment}{* minnlcoptguardsmoothness() for C0/C1 checks}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9418 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9419 \textcolor{comment}{Following flags are set when these errors are suspected:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9420 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.badgradsuspected, and additionally:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9421 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradfidx for specific function (Jacobian row) suspected}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9422 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradvidx for specific variable (Jacobian column) suspected}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9423 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradxbase, a point where gradient/Jacobian is tested}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9424 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgraduser, user-\/provided gradient/Jacobian}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9425 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradnum, reference gradient/Jacobian obtained via numerical}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9426 \textcolor{comment}{    differentiation}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9427 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc0suspected, and additionally:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9428 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.nonc0fidx -\/ an index of specific function violating C0 continuity}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9429 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1suspected, and additionally}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9430 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.nonc1fidx -\/ an index of specific function violating C1 continuity}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9431 \textcolor{comment}{Here function index 0 means  target function, index 1  or  higher  denotes}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9432 \textcolor{comment}{nonlinear constraints.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9433 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9434 \textcolor{comment}{=== ADDITIONAL REPORTS/LOGS ==============================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9435 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9436 \textcolor{comment}{Several different tests are performed to catch C0/C1 errors, you can  find}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9437 \textcolor{comment}{out specific test signaled error by looking to:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9438 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc0test0positive, for non-\/C0 test \#0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9439 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1test0positive, for non-\/C1 test \#0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9440 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1test1positive, for non-\/C1 test \#1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9441 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9442 \textcolor{comment}{Additional information (including line search logs)  can  be  obtained  by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9443 \textcolor{comment}{means of:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9444 \textcolor{comment}{* minnlcoptguardnonc1test0results()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9445 \textcolor{comment}{* minnlcoptguardnonc1test1results()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9446 \textcolor{comment}{which return detailed error reports, specific points where discontinuities}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9447 \textcolor{comment}{were found, and so on.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9448 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9449 \textcolor{comment}{==========================================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9450 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9451 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9452 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9453 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9454 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9455 \textcolor{comment}{    rep     -\/   generic OptGuard report;  more  detailed  reports  can  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9456 \textcolor{comment}{                retrieved with other functions.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9457 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9458 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: false negatives (nonsmooth problems are not identified as  nonsmooth}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9459 \textcolor{comment}{      ones) are possible although unlikely.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9460 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9461 \textcolor{comment}{      The reason  is  that  you  need  to  make several evaluations around}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9462 \textcolor{comment}{      nonsmoothness  in  order  to  accumulate  enough  information  about}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9463 \textcolor{comment}{      function curvature. Say, if you start right from the nonsmooth point,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9464 \textcolor{comment}{      optimizer simply won't get enough data to understand what  is  going}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9465 \textcolor{comment}{      wrong before it terminates due to abrupt changes in the  derivative.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9466 \textcolor{comment}{      It is also  possible  that  "{}unlucky"{}  step  will  move  us  to  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9467 \textcolor{comment}{      termination too quickly.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9468 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9469 \textcolor{comment}{      Our current approach is to have less than 0.1\%  false  negatives  in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9470 \textcolor{comment}{      our test examples  (measured  with  multiple  restarts  from  random}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9471 \textcolor{comment}{      points), and to have exactly 0\% false positives.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9472 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9473 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9474 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 21.11.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9475 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9480 \textcolor{comment}{Detailed results of the OptGuard integrity check for nonsmoothness test \#0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9481 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9482 \textcolor{comment}{Nonsmoothness (non-\/C1) test \#0 studies  function  values  (not  gradient!)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9483 \textcolor{comment}{obtained during line searches and monitors  behavior  of  the  directional}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9486 \textcolor{comment}{This test is less powerful than test \#1, but it does  not  depend  on  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9487 \textcolor{comment}{gradient values and thus it is more robust against artifacts introduced by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9488 \textcolor{comment}{numerical differentiation.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9489 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9490 \textcolor{comment}{Two reports are returned:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9491 \textcolor{comment}{* a "{}strongest"{} one, corresponding  to  line   search  which  had  highest}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9492 \textcolor{comment}{  value of the nonsmoothness indicator}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9493 \textcolor{comment}{* a "{}longest"{} one, corresponding to line search which  had  more  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9494 \textcolor{comment}{  evaluations, and thus is more detailed}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9495 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9496 \textcolor{comment}{In both cases following fields are returned:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9497 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9498 \textcolor{comment}{* positive -\/ is TRUE  when test flagged suspicious point;  FALSE  if  test}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9499 \textcolor{comment}{  did not notice anything (in the latter cases fields below are empty).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9500 \textcolor{comment}{* fidx -\/ is an index of the function (0 for  target  function, 1 or higher}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9502 \textcolor{comment}{* x0[], d[] -\/ arrays of length N which store initial point  and  direction}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9503 \textcolor{comment}{  for line search (d[] can be normalized, but does not have to)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9504 \textcolor{comment}{* stp[], f[] -\/ arrays of length CNT which store step lengths and  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9505 \textcolor{comment}{  values at these points; f[i] is evaluated in x0+stp[i]*d.}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9529 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9530 \textcolor{comment}{Detailed results of the OptGuard integrity check for nonsmoothness test \#1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9531 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9532 \textcolor{comment}{Nonsmoothness (non-\/C1)  test  \#1  studies  individual  components  of  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9533 \textcolor{comment}{gradient computed during line search.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9534 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9535 \textcolor{comment}{When precise analytic gradient is provided this test is more powerful than}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9536 \textcolor{comment}{test \#0  which  works  with  function  values  and  ignores  user-\/provided}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9537 \textcolor{comment}{gradient.  However,  test  \#0  becomes  more   powerful   when   numerical}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9538 \textcolor{comment}{differentiation is employed (in such cases test \#1 detects  higher  levels}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9539 \textcolor{comment}{of numerical noise and becomes too conservative).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9540 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9541 \textcolor{comment}{This test also tells specific components of the gradient which violate  C1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9542 \textcolor{comment}{continuity, which makes it more informative than \#0, which just tells that}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9543 \textcolor{comment}{continuity is violated.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9544 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9545 \textcolor{comment}{Two reports are returned:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9546 \textcolor{comment}{* a "{}strongest"{} one, corresponding  to  line   search  which  had  highest}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9547 \textcolor{comment}{  value of the nonsmoothness indicator}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9548 \textcolor{comment}{* a "{}longest"{} one, corresponding to line search which  had  more  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9549 \textcolor{comment}{  evaluations, and thus is more detailed}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9550 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9551 \textcolor{comment}{In both cases following fields are returned:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9552 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9553 \textcolor{comment}{* positive -\/ is TRUE  when test flagged suspicious point;  FALSE  if  test}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9554 \textcolor{comment}{  did not notice anything (in the latter cases fields below are empty).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9555 \textcolor{comment}{* fidx -\/ is an index of the function (0 for  target  function, 1 or higher}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9556 \textcolor{comment}{  for nonlinear constraints) which is suspected of being "{}non-\/C1"{}}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9557 \textcolor{comment}{* vidx -\/ is an index of the variable in [0,N) with nonsmooth derivative}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9558 \textcolor{comment}{* x0[], d[] -\/ arrays of length N which store initial point  and  direction}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9564 \textcolor{comment}{  between steps \#stpidxa and \#stpidxb (usually we have  stpidxb=stpidxa+3,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9565 \textcolor{comment}{  with  most  likely  position  of  the  violation  between  stpidxa+1 and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9566 \textcolor{comment}{  stpidxa+2.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9567 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9568 \textcolor{comment}{==========================================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9569 \textcolor{comment}{= SHORTLY SPEAKING: build a 2D plot of (stp,f) and look at it -\/  you  will}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9571 \textcolor{comment}{==========================================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9572 \textcolor{comment}{}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9574 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9576 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9695 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9696 \textcolor{comment}{                  NONSMOOTH NONCONVEX OPTIMIZATION}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9697 \textcolor{comment}{            SUBJECT TO BOX/LINEAR/NONLINEAR-\/NONSMOOTH CONSTRAINTS}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9698 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9699 \textcolor{comment}{DESCRIPTION:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9700 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9701 \textcolor{comment}{The  subroutine  minimizes  function   F(x)  of N arguments subject to any}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9702 \textcolor{comment}{combination of:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9703 \textcolor{comment}{* bound constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9704 \textcolor{comment}{* linear inequality constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9705 \textcolor{comment}{* linear equality constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9706 \textcolor{comment}{* nonlinear equality constraints Gi(x)=0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9707 \textcolor{comment}{* nonlinear inequality constraints Hi(x)<=0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9708 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9709 \textcolor{comment}{IMPORTANT: see MinNSSetAlgoAGS for important  information  on  performance}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9710 \textcolor{comment}{           restrictions of AGS solver.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9711 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9712 \textcolor{comment}{REQUIREMENTS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9713 \textcolor{comment}{* starting point X0 must be feasible or not too far away from the feasible}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9714 \textcolor{comment}{  set}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9715 \textcolor{comment}{* F(), G(), H() are continuous, locally Lipschitz  and  continuously  (but}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9716 \textcolor{comment}{  not necessarily twice) differentiable in an open dense  subset  of  R\string^N.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9717 \textcolor{comment}{  Functions F(), G() and H() may be nonsmooth and non-\/convex.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9718 \textcolor{comment}{  Informally speaking, it means  that  functions  are  composed  of  large}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9719 \textcolor{comment}{  differentiable "{}patches"{} with nonsmoothness having  place  only  at  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9720 \textcolor{comment}{  boundaries between these "{}patches"{}.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9721 \textcolor{comment}{  Most real-\/life nonsmooth  functions  satisfy  these  requirements.  Say,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9722 \textcolor{comment}{  anything which involves finite number of abs(), min() and max() is  very}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9723 \textcolor{comment}{  likely to pass the test.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9724 \textcolor{comment}{  Say, it is possible to optimize anything of the following:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9725 \textcolor{comment}{  * f=abs(x0)+2*abs(x1)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9726 \textcolor{comment}{  * f=max(x0,x1)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9727 \textcolor{comment}{  * f=sin(max(x0,x1)+abs(x2))}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9728 \textcolor{comment}{* for nonlinearly constrained problems: F()  must  be  bounded from  below}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9729 \textcolor{comment}{  without nonlinear constraints (this requirement is due to the fact that,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9730 \textcolor{comment}{  contrary to box and linear constraints, nonlinear ones  require  special}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9731 \textcolor{comment}{  handling).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9732 \textcolor{comment}{* user must provide function value and gradient for F(), H(), G()  at  all}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9733 \textcolor{comment}{  points where function/gradient can be calculated. If optimizer  requires}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9734 \textcolor{comment}{  value exactly at the boundary between "{}patches"{} (say, at x=0 for f=abs(x)),}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9735 \textcolor{comment}{  where gradient is not defined, user may resolve tie arbitrarily (in  our}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9736 \textcolor{comment}{  case -\/ return +1 or -\/1 at its discretion).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9737 \textcolor{comment}{* NS solver supports numerical differentiation, i.e. it may  differentiate}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9738 \textcolor{comment}{  your function for you,  but  it  results  in  2N  increase  of  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9739 \textcolor{comment}{  evaluations. Not recommended unless you solve really small problems. See}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9740 \textcolor{comment}{  minnscreatef() for more information on this functionality.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9741 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9742 \textcolor{comment}{USAGE:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9743 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9744 \textcolor{comment}{1. User initializes algorithm state with MinNSCreate() call  and   chooses}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9745 \textcolor{comment}{   what NLC solver to use. There is some solver which is used by  default,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9746 \textcolor{comment}{   with default settings, but you should NOT rely on  default  choice.  It}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9747 \textcolor{comment}{   may change in future releases of ALGLIB without notice, and no one  can}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9748 \textcolor{comment}{   guarantee that new solver will be  able  to  solve  your  problem  with}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9749 \textcolor{comment}{   default settings.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9750 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9751 \textcolor{comment}{   From the other side, if you choose solver explicitly, you can be pretty}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9752 \textcolor{comment}{   sure that it will work with new ALGLIB releases.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9753 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9754 \textcolor{comment}{   In the current release following solvers can be used:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9755 \textcolor{comment}{   * AGS solver (activated with MinNSSetAlgoAGS() function)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9756 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9757 \textcolor{comment}{2. User adds boundary and/or linear and/or nonlinear constraints by  means}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9758 \textcolor{comment}{   of calling one of the following functions:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9759 \textcolor{comment}{   a) MinNSSetBC() for boundary constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9760 \textcolor{comment}{   b) MinNSSetLC() for linear constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9761 \textcolor{comment}{   c) MinNSSetNLC() for nonlinear constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9762 \textcolor{comment}{   You may combine (a), (b) and (c) in one optimization problem.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9763 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9764 \textcolor{comment}{3. User sets scale of the variables with MinNSSetScale() function. It   is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9765 \textcolor{comment}{   VERY important to set  scale  of  the  variables,  because  nonlinearly}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9766 \textcolor{comment}{   constrained problems are hard to solve when variables are badly scaled.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9767 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9768 \textcolor{comment}{4. User sets stopping conditions with MinNSSetCond().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9769 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9770 \textcolor{comment}{5. Finally, user calls MinNSOptimize()  function  which  takes   algorithm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9771 \textcolor{comment}{   state and pointer (delegate, etc) to callback function which calculates}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9772 \textcolor{comment}{   F/G/H.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9773 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9774 \textcolor{comment}{7. User calls MinNSResults() to get solution}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9775 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9776 \textcolor{comment}{8. Optionally user may call MinNSRestartFrom() to solve   another  problem}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9777 \textcolor{comment}{   with same N but another starting point. MinNSRestartFrom()  allows   to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9778 \textcolor{comment}{   reuse already initialized structure.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9779 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9780 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9781 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9782 \textcolor{comment}{    N       -\/   problem dimension, N>0:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9783 \textcolor{comment}{                * if given, only leading N elements of X are used}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9784 \textcolor{comment}{                * if not given, automatically determined from size of X}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9785 \textcolor{comment}{    X       -\/   starting point, array[N]:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9786 \textcolor{comment}{                * it is better to set X to a feasible point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9787 \textcolor{comment}{                * but X can be infeasible, in which case algorithm will try}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9788 \textcolor{comment}{                  to find feasible point first, using X as initial}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9789 \textcolor{comment}{                  approximation.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9790 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9791 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9792 \textcolor{comment}{    State   -\/   structure stores algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9793 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9794 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: minnscreatef() function may be used if  you  do  not  have  analytic}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9795 \textcolor{comment}{      gradient.   This   function  creates  solver  which  uses  numerical}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9796 \textcolor{comment}{      differentiation with user-\/specified step.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9797 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9798 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9799 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 18.05.2015 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9800 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9806 \textcolor{comment}{Version of minnscreatef() which uses numerical differentiation. I.e.,  you}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9807 \textcolor{comment}{do not have to calculate derivatives yourself. However, this version needs}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9810 \textcolor{comment}{2-\/point differentiation formula is  used,  because  more  precise  4-\/point}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9926 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: you may combine nonlinear constraints with linear/boundary ones.  If}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9927 \textcolor{comment}{      your problem has mixed constraints, you  may explicitly specify some}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9928 \textcolor{comment}{      of them as linear ones. It may help optimizer to  handle  them  more}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9931 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}

\DoxyCodeLine{9935 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9936 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE 1: nonlinear constraints are satisfied only  approximately!   It   is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9937 \textcolor{comment}{        possible   that  algorithm  will  evaluate  function  outside   of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9938 \textcolor{comment}{        the feasible area!}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9939 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9940 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE 2: algorithm scales variables  according  to   scale   specified   by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9941 \textcolor{comment}{        minnssetscale()  function,  so  it can handle problems with  badly}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9942 \textcolor{comment}{        scaled variables (as long as we KNOW their scales).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9943 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9944 \textcolor{comment}{        However,  there  is  no  way  to  automatically  scale   nonlinear}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9945 \textcolor{comment}{        constraints Gi(x) and Hi(x). Inappropriate scaling  of  Gi/Hi  may}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9946 \textcolor{comment}{        ruin convergence. Solving problem with  constraint  "{}1000*G0(x)=0"{}}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9947 \textcolor{comment}{        is NOT same as solving it with constraint "{}0.001*G0(x)=0"{}.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9948 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9949 \textcolor{comment}{        It  means  that  YOU  are  the  one who is responsible for correct}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9950 \textcolor{comment}{        scaling of nonlinear constraints Gi(x) and Hi(x). We recommend you}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9951 \textcolor{comment}{        to scale nonlinear constraints in such way that I-\/th component  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9952 \textcolor{comment}{        dG/dX (or dH/dx) has approximately unit  magnitude  (for  problems}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9953 \textcolor{comment}{        with unit scale)  or  has  magnitude approximately equal to 1/S[i]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9954 \textcolor{comment}{        (where S is a scale set by minnssetscale() function).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9955 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9956 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE 3: nonlinear constraints are always hard to handle,  no  matter  what}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9957 \textcolor{comment}{        algorithm you try to use. Even basic box/linear constraints modify}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9958 \textcolor{comment}{        function  curvature   by  adding   valleys  and  ridges.  However,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9959 \textcolor{comment}{        nonlinear constraints add valleys which are very  hard  to  follow}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9960 \textcolor{comment}{        due to their "{}curved"{} nature.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9961 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9962 \textcolor{comment}{        It means that optimization with single nonlinear constraint may be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9963 \textcolor{comment}{        significantly slower than optimization with multiple linear  ones.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9964 \textcolor{comment}{        It is normal situation, and we recommend you to  carefully  choose}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9965 \textcolor{comment}{        Rho parameter of minnssetalgoags(), because too  large  value  may}}
\DoxyCodeLine{9966 \textcolor{comment}{        slow down convergence.}}

\DoxyCodeLine{10019 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10020 \textcolor{comment}{This function tells MinNS unit to use  AGS  (adaptive  gradient  sampling)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10021 \textcolor{comment}{algorithm for nonsmooth constrained  optimization.  This  algorithm  is  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10022 \textcolor{comment}{slight modification of one described in  "{}An  Adaptive  Gradient  Sampling}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10023 \textcolor{comment}{Algorithm for Nonsmooth Optimization"{} by Frank E. Curtisy and Xiaocun Quez.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10024 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10025 \textcolor{comment}{This optimizer has following benefits and drawbacks:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10026 \textcolor{comment}{+ robustness; it can be used with nonsmooth and nonconvex functions.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10027 \textcolor{comment}{+ relatively easy tuning; most of the metaparameters are easy to select.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10028 \textcolor{comment}{-\/ it has convergence of steepest descent, slower than CG/LBFGS.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10029 \textcolor{comment}{-\/ each iteration involves evaluation of \string~2N gradient values  and  solution}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10030 \textcolor{comment}{  of 2Nx2N quadratic programming problem, which  limits  applicability  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10031 \textcolor{comment}{  algorithm by small-\/scale problems (up to 50-\/100).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10032 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10033 \textcolor{comment}{IMPORTANT: this  algorithm  has  convergence  guarantees,   i.e.  it  will}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10034 \textcolor{comment}{           steadily move towards some stationary point of the function.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10035 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10036 \textcolor{comment}{           However, "{}stationary point"{} does not  always  mean  "{}solution"{}.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10037 \textcolor{comment}{           Nonsmooth problems often have "{}flat spots"{},  i.e.  areas  where}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10038 \textcolor{comment}{           function do not change at all. Such "{}flat spots"{} are stationary}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10039 \textcolor{comment}{           points by definition, and algorithm may be caught here.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10040 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10041 \textcolor{comment}{           Nonsmooth CONVEX tasks are not prone to  this  problem. Say, if}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10042 \textcolor{comment}{           your function has form f()=MAX(f0,f1,...), and f\_i are  convex,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10043 \textcolor{comment}{           then f() is convex too and you have guaranteed  convergence  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10044 \textcolor{comment}{           solution.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10045 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10046 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10047 \textcolor{comment}{    State   -\/   structure which stores algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10048 \textcolor{comment}{    Radius  -\/   initial sampling radius, >=0.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10049 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10050 \textcolor{comment}{                Internally multiplied  by  vector of  per-\/variable  scales}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10051 \textcolor{comment}{                specified by minnssetscale()).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10052 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10053 \textcolor{comment}{                You should select relatively large sampling radius, roughly}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10054 \textcolor{comment}{                proportional to scaled length of the first  steps  of  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10055 \textcolor{comment}{                algorithm. Something close to 0.1 in magnitude  should  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10056 \textcolor{comment}{                good for most problems.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10057 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10058 \textcolor{comment}{                AGS solver can automatically decrease radius, so too large}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10059 \textcolor{comment}{                radius is  not a problem (assuming that you  won't  choose}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10060 \textcolor{comment}{                so large radius that algorithm  will  sample  function  in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10061 \textcolor{comment}{                too far away points, where gradient value is irrelevant).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10062 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10063 \textcolor{comment}{                Too small radius won't cause algorithm to fail, but it may}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10064 \textcolor{comment}{                slow down algorithm (it may  have  to  perform  too  short}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10065 \textcolor{comment}{                steps).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10066 \textcolor{comment}{    Penalty -\/   penalty coefficient for nonlinear constraints:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10067 \textcolor{comment}{                * for problem with nonlinear constraints  should  be  some}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10068 \textcolor{comment}{                  problem-\/specific  positive   value,  large  enough  that}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10069 \textcolor{comment}{                  penalty term changes shape of the function.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10070 \textcolor{comment}{                  Starting  from  some  problem-\/specific   value   penalty}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10071 \textcolor{comment}{                  coefficient becomes  large  enough  to  exactly  enforce}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10072 \textcolor{comment}{                  nonlinear constraints;  larger  values  do  not  improve}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10073 \textcolor{comment}{                  precision.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10074 \textcolor{comment}{                  Increasing it too much may slow down convergence, so you}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10075 \textcolor{comment}{                  should choose it carefully.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10076 \textcolor{comment}{                * can be zero for problems WITHOUT  nonlinear  constraints}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10077 \textcolor{comment}{                  (i.e. for unconstrained ones or ones with  just  box  or}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10078 \textcolor{comment}{                  linear constraints)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10079 \textcolor{comment}{                * if you specify zero value for problem with at least  one}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10080 \textcolor{comment}{                  nonlinear  constraint,  algorithm  will  terminate  with}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10081 \textcolor{comment}{                  error code -\/1.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10082 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10083 \textcolor{comment}{ALGORITHM OUTLINE}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10084 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10085 \textcolor{comment}{The very basic outline of unconstrained AGS algorithm is given below:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10086 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10087 \textcolor{comment}{0. If sampling radius is below EpsX  or  we  performed  more  then  MaxIts}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10088 \textcolor{comment}{   iterations -\/ STOP.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10089 \textcolor{comment}{1. sample O(N) gradient values at random locations  around  current point;}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10090 \textcolor{comment}{   informally speaking, this sample is an implicit piecewise  linear model}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10091 \textcolor{comment}{   of the function, although algorithm formulation does  not  mention that}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10092 \textcolor{comment}{   explicitly}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10093 \textcolor{comment}{2. solve quadratic programming problem in order to find descent direction}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10094 \textcolor{comment}{3. if QP solver tells us that we  are  near  solution,  decrease  sampling}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10095 \textcolor{comment}{   radius and move to (0)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10096 \textcolor{comment}{4. perform backtracking line search}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10097 \textcolor{comment}{5. after moving to new point, goto (0)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10098 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10099 \textcolor{comment}{Constraint handling details:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10100 \textcolor{comment}{* box constraints are handled exactly by algorithm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10101 \textcolor{comment}{* linear/nonlinear constraints are handled by adding L1  penalty.  Because}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10102 \textcolor{comment}{  our solver can handle nonsmoothness, we can  use  L1  penalty  function,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10103 \textcolor{comment}{  which is an exact one  (i.e.  exact  solution  is  returned  under  such}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10104 \textcolor{comment}{  penalty).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10105 \textcolor{comment}{* penalty coefficient for  linear  constraints  is  chosen  automatically;}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10106 \textcolor{comment}{  however, penalty coefficient for nonlinear constraints must be specified}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10107 \textcolor{comment}{  by user.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10108 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10109 \textcolor{comment}{===== TRACING AGS SOLVER =================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10110 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10111 \textcolor{comment}{AGS solver supports advanced tracing capabilities. You can trace algorithm}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10112 \textcolor{comment}{output by specifying following trace symbols (case-\/insensitive)  by  means}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10113 \textcolor{comment}{of trace\_file() call:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10114 \textcolor{comment}{* 'AGS'         -\/ for basic trace of algorithm  steps and decisions.  Only}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10115 \textcolor{comment}{                  short scalars (function values and deltas) are  printed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10116 \textcolor{comment}{                  N-\/dimensional quantities like search directions are  NOT}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10117 \textcolor{comment}{                  printed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10118 \textcolor{comment}{* 'AGS.DETAILED'-\/ for output of points being visited and search directions}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10119 \textcolor{comment}{                  This  symbol  also  implicitly  defines  'AGS'. You  can}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10120 \textcolor{comment}{                  control output format by additionally specifying:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10121 \textcolor{comment}{                  * nothing     to output in  6-\/digit exponential format}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10122 \textcolor{comment}{                  * 'PREC.E15'  to output in 15-\/digit exponential format}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10123 \textcolor{comment}{                  * 'PREC.F6'   to output in  6-\/digit fixed-\/point format}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10124 \textcolor{comment}{* 'AGS.DETAILED.SAMPLE'-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10125 \textcolor{comment}{                  for output of points being visited ,  search  directions}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10126 \textcolor{comment}{                  and gradient sample. May take a LOT of  space ,  do  not}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10127 \textcolor{comment}{                  use it on problems with more that several tens of vars.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10128 \textcolor{comment}{                  This  symbol   also    implicitly   defines   'AGS'  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10129 \textcolor{comment}{                  'AGS.DETAILED'.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10130 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10131 \textcolor{comment}{By default trace is disabled and adds  no  overhead  to  the  optimization}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10132 \textcolor{comment}{process. However, specifying any of the symbols adds some  formatting  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10133 \textcolor{comment}{output-\/related overhead.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10134 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10135 \textcolor{comment}{You may specify multiple symbols by separating them with commas:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10136 \textcolor{comment}{>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10137 \textcolor{comment}{> alglib::trace\_file("{}AGS,PREC.F6"{}, "{}path/to/trace.log"{})}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10138 \textcolor{comment}{>}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10139 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10140 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10141 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10142 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 18.05.2015 by Bochkanov Sergey}}

\DoxyCodeLine{10471 \textcolor{comment}{                     BOX CONSTRAINED OPTIMIZATION}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10472 \textcolor{comment}{          WITH FAST ACTIVATION OF MULTIPLE BOX CONSTRAINTS}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10473 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10474 \textcolor{comment}{DESCRIPTION:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10475 \textcolor{comment}{The  subroutine  minimizes  function   F(x) of N arguments subject  to box}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10476 \textcolor{comment}{constraints (with some of box constraints actually being equality ones).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10477 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10478 \textcolor{comment}{This optimizer uses algorithm similar to that of MinBLEIC (optimizer  with}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10479 \textcolor{comment}{general linear constraints), but presence of box-\/only  constraints  allows}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10480 \textcolor{comment}{us to use faster constraint activation strategies. On large-\/scale problems,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10481 \textcolor{comment}{with multiple constraints active at the solution, this  optimizer  can  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10482 \textcolor{comment}{several times faster than BLEIC.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10483 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10484 \textcolor{comment}{REQUIREMENTS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10485 \textcolor{comment}{* user must provide function value and gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10486 \textcolor{comment}{* starting point X0 must be feasible or}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10487 \textcolor{comment}{  not too far away from the feasible set}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10488 \textcolor{comment}{* grad(f) must be Lipschitz continuous on a level set:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10489 \textcolor{comment}{  L = \{ x : f(x)<=f(x0) \}}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10490 \textcolor{comment}{* function must be defined everywhere on the feasible set F}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10491 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10492 \textcolor{comment}{USAGE:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10493 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10494 \textcolor{comment}{Constrained optimization if far more complex than the unconstrained one.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10495 \textcolor{comment}{Here we give very brief outline of the BC optimizer. We strongly recommend}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10496 \textcolor{comment}{you to read examples in the ALGLIB Reference Manual and to read ALGLIB User Guide}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10497 \textcolor{comment}{on optimization, which is available at http://www.alglib.net/optimization/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10498 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10499 \textcolor{comment}{1. User initializes algorithm state with MinBCCreate() call}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10500 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10501 \textcolor{comment}{2. USer adds box constraints by calling MinBCSetBC() function.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10502 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10503 \textcolor{comment}{3. User sets stopping conditions with MinBCSetCond().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10504 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10505 \textcolor{comment}{4. User calls MinBCOptimize() function which takes algorithm  state and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10506 \textcolor{comment}{   pointer (delegate, etc.) to callback function which calculates F/G.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10507 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10508 \textcolor{comment}{5. User calls MinBCResults() to get solution}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10509 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10510 \textcolor{comment}{6. Optionally user may call MinBCRestartFrom() to solve another problem}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10511 \textcolor{comment}{   with same N but another starting point.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10512 \textcolor{comment}{   MinBCRestartFrom() allows to reuse already initialized structure.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10513 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10514 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10515 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10516 \textcolor{comment}{    N       -\/   problem dimension, N>0:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10517 \textcolor{comment}{                * if given, only leading N elements of X are used}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10518 \textcolor{comment}{                * if not given, automatically determined from size ofX}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10519 \textcolor{comment}{    X       -\/   starting point, array[N]:}}

\DoxyCodeLine{10535 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10536 \textcolor{comment}{The subroutine is finite difference variant of MinBCCreate().  It  uses}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10537 \textcolor{comment}{finite differences in order to differentiate target function.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10538 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10539 \textcolor{comment}{Description below contains information which is specific to  this function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10540 \textcolor{comment}{only. We recommend to read comments on MinBCCreate() in  order  to  get}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10541 \textcolor{comment}{more information about creation of BC optimizer.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10542 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10543 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10544 \textcolor{comment}{    N       -\/   problem dimension, N>0:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10545 \textcolor{comment}{                * if given, only leading N elements of X are used}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10546 \textcolor{comment}{                * if not given, automatically determined from size of X}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10547 \textcolor{comment}{    X       -\/   starting point, array[0..N-\/1].}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10548 \textcolor{comment}{    DiffStep-\/   differentiation step, >0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10549 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10550 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10551 \textcolor{comment}{    State   -\/   structure which stores algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10552 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10553 \textcolor{comment}{NOTES:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10554 \textcolor{comment}{1. algorithm uses 4-\/point central formula for differentiation.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10555 \textcolor{comment}{2. differentiation step along I-\/th axis is equal to DiffStep*S[I] where}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10556 \textcolor{comment}{   S[] is scaling vector which can be set by MinBCSetScale() call.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10557 \textcolor{comment}{3. we recommend you to use moderate values of  differentiation  step.  Too}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10558 \textcolor{comment}{   large step will result in too large truncation  errors, while too small}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10559 \textcolor{comment}{   step will result in too large numerical  errors.  1.0E-\/6  can  be  good}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10560 \textcolor{comment}{   value to start with.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10561 \textcolor{comment}{4. Numerical  differentiation  is   very   inefficient  -\/   one   gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10562 \textcolor{comment}{   calculation needs 4*N function evaluations. This function will work for}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10563 \textcolor{comment}{   any N -\/ either small (1...10), moderate (10...100) or  large  (100...).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10564 \textcolor{comment}{   However, performance penalty will be too severe for any N's except  for}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10565 \textcolor{comment}{   small ones.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10566 \textcolor{comment}{   We should also say that code which relies on numerical  differentiation}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10567 \textcolor{comment}{   is  less  robust and precise. CG needs exact gradient values. Imprecise}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10568 \textcolor{comment}{   gradient may slow  down  convergence, especially  on  highly  nonlinear}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10569 \textcolor{comment}{   problems.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10570 \textcolor{comment}{   Thus  we  recommend to use this function for fast prototyping on small-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10571 \textcolor{comment}{   dimensional problems only, and to implement analytical gradient as soon}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10572 \textcolor{comment}{   as possible.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10573 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10574 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10575 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 16.05.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey}}

\DoxyCodeLine{10846 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10847 \textcolor{comment}{This  function  activates/deactivates verification  of  the  user-\/supplied}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10848 \textcolor{comment}{analytic gradient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10849 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10850 \textcolor{comment}{Upon  activation  of  this  option  OptGuard  integrity  checker  performs}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10851 \textcolor{comment}{numerical differentiation of your target function  at  the  initial  point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10852 \textcolor{comment}{(note: future versions may also perform check  at  the  final  point)  and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10853 \textcolor{comment}{compares numerical gradient with analytic one provided by you.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10854 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10855 \textcolor{comment}{If difference is too large, an error flag is set and optimization  session}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10856 \textcolor{comment}{continues. After optimization session is over, you can retrieve the report}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10857 \textcolor{comment}{which  stores  both  gradients  and  specific  components  highlighted  as}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10858 \textcolor{comment}{suspicious by the OptGuard.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10859 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10860 \textcolor{comment}{The primary OptGuard report can be retrieved with minbcoptguardresults().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10861 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10862 \textcolor{comment}{IMPORTANT: gradient check is a high-\/overhead option which  will  cost  you}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10863 \textcolor{comment}{           about 3*N additional function evaluations. In many cases it may}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10864 \textcolor{comment}{           cost as much as the rest of the optimization session.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10865 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10866 \textcolor{comment}{           YOU SHOULD NOT USE IT IN THE PRODUCTION CODE UNLESS YOU WANT TO}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10867 \textcolor{comment}{           CHECK DERIVATIVES PROVIDED BY SOME THIRD PARTY.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10868 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10869 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: unlike previous incarnation of the gradient checking code,  OptGuard}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10870 \textcolor{comment}{      does NOT interrupt optimization even if it discovers bad gradient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10871 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10872 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10873 \textcolor{comment}{    State       -\/   structure used to store algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10874 \textcolor{comment}{    TestStep    -\/   verification step used for numerical differentiation:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10875 \textcolor{comment}{                    * TestStep=0 turns verification off}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10876 \textcolor{comment}{                    * TestStep>0 activates verification}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10877 \textcolor{comment}{                    You should carefully choose TestStep. Value  which  is}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10878 \textcolor{comment}{                    too large (so large that  function  behavior  is  non-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10879 \textcolor{comment}{                    cubic at this scale) will lead  to  false  alarms. Too}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10880 \textcolor{comment}{                    short step will result in rounding  errors  dominating}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10881 \textcolor{comment}{                    numerical derivative.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10882 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10883 \textcolor{comment}{                    You may use different step for different parameters by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10884 \textcolor{comment}{                    means of setting scale with minbcsetscale().}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10885 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10886 \textcolor{comment}{=== EXPLANATION ==========================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10887 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10888 \textcolor{comment}{In order to verify gradient algorithm performs following steps:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10889 \textcolor{comment}{  * two trial steps are made to X[i]-\/TestStep*S[i] and X[i]+TestStep*S[i],}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10890 \textcolor{comment}{    where X[i] is i-\/th component of the initial point and S[i] is a  scale}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10891 \textcolor{comment}{    of i-\/th parameter}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10892 \textcolor{comment}{  * F(X) is evaluated at these trial points}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10893 \textcolor{comment}{  * we perform one more evaluation in the middle point of the interval}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10894 \textcolor{comment}{  * we  build  cubic  model using function values and derivatives at trial}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10895 \textcolor{comment}{    points and we compare its prediction with actual value in  the  middle}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10896 \textcolor{comment}{    point}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10897 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10898 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10899 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 15.06.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10900 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{10904 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10905 \textcolor{comment}{This  function  activates/deactivates nonsmoothness monitoring  option  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10906 \textcolor{comment}{the  OptGuard  integrity  checker. Smoothness  monitor  silently  observes}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10907 \textcolor{comment}{solution process and tries to detect ill-\/posed problems, i.e. ones with:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10908 \textcolor{comment}{a) discontinuous target function (non-\/C0)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10909 \textcolor{comment}{b) nonsmooth     target function (non-\/C1)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10910 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10911 \textcolor{comment}{Smoothness monitoring does NOT interrupt optimization  even if it suspects}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10912 \textcolor{comment}{that your problem is nonsmooth. It just sets corresponding  flags  in  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10913 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard report which can be retrieved after optimization is over.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10914 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10915 \textcolor{comment}{Smoothness monitoring is a moderate overhead option which often adds  less}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10916 \textcolor{comment}{than 1\% to the optimizer running time. Thus, you can use it even for large}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10917 \textcolor{comment}{scale problems.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10918 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10919 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: OptGuard does  NOT  guarantee  that  it  will  always  detect  C0/C1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10920 \textcolor{comment}{      continuity violations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10921 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10922 \textcolor{comment}{      First, minor errors are hard to  catch -\/ say, a 0.0001 difference in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10923 \textcolor{comment}{      the model values at two sides of the gap may be due to discontinuity}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10924 \textcolor{comment}{      of the model -\/ or simply because the model has changed.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10925 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10926 \textcolor{comment}{      Second, C1-\/violations  are  especially  difficult  to  detect  in  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10927 \textcolor{comment}{      noninvasive way. The optimizer usually  performs  very  short  steps}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10928 \textcolor{comment}{      near the nonsmoothness, and differentiation  usually   introduces  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10929 \textcolor{comment}{      lot of numerical noise.  It  is  hard  to  tell  whether  some  tiny}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10930 \textcolor{comment}{      discontinuity in the slope is due to real nonsmoothness or just  due}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10931 \textcolor{comment}{      to numerical noise alone.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10932 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10933 \textcolor{comment}{      Our top priority was to avoid false positives, so in some rare cases}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10934 \textcolor{comment}{      minor errors may went unnoticed (however, in most cases they can  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10935 \textcolor{comment}{      spotted with restart from different initial point).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10936 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10937 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10938 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10939 \textcolor{comment}{    level   -\/   monitoring level:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10940 \textcolor{comment}{                * 0 -\/ monitoring is disabled}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10941 \textcolor{comment}{                * 1 -\/ noninvasive low-\/overhead monitoring; function values}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10942 \textcolor{comment}{                      and/or gradients are recorded, but OptGuard does not}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10943 \textcolor{comment}{                      try to perform additional evaluations  in  order  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10944 \textcolor{comment}{                      get more information about suspicious locations.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10945 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10946 \textcolor{comment}{=== EXPLANATION ==========================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10947 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10948 \textcolor{comment}{One major source of headache during optimization  is  the  possibility  of}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10949 \textcolor{comment}{the coding errors in the target function/constraints (or their gradients).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10950 \textcolor{comment}{Such  errors   most   often   manifest   themselves  as  discontinuity  or}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10951 \textcolor{comment}{nonsmoothness of the target/constraints.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10952 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10953 \textcolor{comment}{Another frequent situation is when you try to optimize something involving}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10954 \textcolor{comment}{lots of min() and max() operations, i.e. nonsmooth target. Although not  a}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10955 \textcolor{comment}{coding error, it is nonsmoothness anyway -\/ and smooth  optimizers  usually}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10956 \textcolor{comment}{stop right after encountering nonsmoothness, well before reaching solution.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10957 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10958 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard integrity checker helps you to catch such situations: it monitors}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10959 \textcolor{comment}{function values/gradients being passed  to  the  optimizer  and  tries  to}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10960 \textcolor{comment}{errors. Upon discovering suspicious pair of points it  raises  appropriate}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10961 \textcolor{comment}{flag (and allows you to continue optimization). When optimization is done,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10962 \textcolor{comment}{you can study OptGuard result.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10963 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10964 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{10971 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10972 \textcolor{comment}{Results of OptGuard integrity check, should be called  after  optimization}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10973 \textcolor{comment}{session is over.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10974 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10975 \textcolor{comment}{=== PRIMARY REPORT =======================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10976 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10977 \textcolor{comment}{OptGuard performs several checks which are intended to catch common errors}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10978 \textcolor{comment}{in the implementation of nonlinear function/gradient:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10979 \textcolor{comment}{* incorrect analytic gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10980 \textcolor{comment}{* discontinuous (non-\/C0) target functions (constraints)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10981 \textcolor{comment}{* nonsmooth     (non-\/C1) target functions (constraints)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10982 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10983 \textcolor{comment}{Each of these checks is activated with appropriate function:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10984 \textcolor{comment}{* minbcoptguardgradient() for gradient verification}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10985 \textcolor{comment}{* minbcoptguardsmoothness() for C0/C1 checks}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10986 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10987 \textcolor{comment}{Following flags are set when these errors are suspected:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10988 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.badgradsuspected, and additionally:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10989 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradvidx for specific variable (gradient element) suspected}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10990 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradxbase, a point where gradient is tested}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10991 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgraduser, user-\/provided gradient  (stored  as  2D  matrix  with}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10992 \textcolor{comment}{    single row in order to make  report  structure  compatible  with  more}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10993 \textcolor{comment}{    complex optimizers like MinNLC or MinLM)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10994 \textcolor{comment}{  * rep.badgradnum,   reference    gradient    obtained    via   numerical}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10995 \textcolor{comment}{    differentiation (stored as  2D matrix with single row in order to make}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10996 \textcolor{comment}{    report structure compatible with more complex optimizers  like  MinNLC}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10997 \textcolor{comment}{    or MinLM)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10998 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc0suspected}}
\DoxyCodeLine{10999 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1suspected}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11000 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11001 \textcolor{comment}{=== ADDITIONAL REPORTS/LOGS ==============================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11002 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11003 \textcolor{comment}{Several different tests are performed to catch C0/C1 errors, you can  find}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11004 \textcolor{comment}{out specific test signaled error by looking to:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11005 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc0test0positive, for non-\/C0 test \#0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11006 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1test0positive, for non-\/C1 test \#0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11007 \textcolor{comment}{* rep.nonc1test1positive, for non-\/C1 test \#1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11008 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11009 \textcolor{comment}{Additional information (including line search logs)  can  be  obtained  by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11010 \textcolor{comment}{means of:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11011 \textcolor{comment}{* minbcoptguardnonc1test0results()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11012 \textcolor{comment}{* minbcoptguardnonc1test1results()}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11013 \textcolor{comment}{which return detailed error reports, specific points where discontinuities}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11014 \textcolor{comment}{were found, and so on.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11015 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11016 \textcolor{comment}{==========================================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11017 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11018 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11019 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11020 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11021 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11022 \textcolor{comment}{    rep     -\/   generic OptGuard report;  more  detailed  reports  can  be}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11023 \textcolor{comment}{                retrieved with other functions.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11024 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11025 \textcolor{comment}{NOTE: false negatives (nonsmooth problems are not identified as  nonsmooth}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11026 \textcolor{comment}{      ones) are possible although unlikely.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11027 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11028 \textcolor{comment}{      The reason  is  that  you  need  to  make several evaluations around}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11029 \textcolor{comment}{      nonsmoothness  in  order  to  accumulate  enough  information  about}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11030 \textcolor{comment}{      function curvature. Say, if you start right from the nonsmooth point,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11031 \textcolor{comment}{      optimizer simply won't get enough data to understand what  is  going}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11032 \textcolor{comment}{      wrong before it terminates due to abrupt changes in the  derivative.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11033 \textcolor{comment}{      It is also  possible  that  "{}unlucky"{}  step  will  move  us  to  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11034 \textcolor{comment}{      termination too quickly.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11035 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11036 \textcolor{comment}{      Our current approach is to have less than 0.1\%  false  negatives  in}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11037 \textcolor{comment}{      our test examples  (measured  with  multiple  restarts  from  random}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11038 \textcolor{comment}{      points), and to have exactly 0\% false positives.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11039 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11040 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11041 \textcolor{comment}{     Copyright 21.11.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11042 \textcolor{comment}{*************************************************************************/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{11046 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11047 \textcolor{comment}{Detailed results of the OptGuard integrity check for nonsmoothness test \#0}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11048 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11049 \textcolor{comment}{Nonsmoothness (non-\/C1) test \#0 studies  function  values  (not  gradient!)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11050 \textcolor{comment}{obtained during line searches and monitors  behavior  of  the  directional}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11051 \textcolor{comment}{derivative estimate.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11052 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11053 \textcolor{comment}{This test is less powerful than test \#1, but it does  not  depend  on  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11054 \textcolor{comment}{gradient values and thus it is more robust against artifacts introduced by}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11055 \textcolor{comment}{numerical differentiation.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11056 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11057 \textcolor{comment}{Two reports are returned:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11058 \textcolor{comment}{* a "{}strongest"{} one, corresponding  to  line   search  which  had  highest}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11059 \textcolor{comment}{  value of the nonsmoothness indicator}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11060 \textcolor{comment}{* a "{}longest"{} one, corresponding to line search which  had  more  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11061 \textcolor{comment}{  evaluations, and thus is more detailed}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11062 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11063 \textcolor{comment}{In both cases following fields are returned:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11064 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11065 \textcolor{comment}{* positive -\/ is TRUE  when test flagged suspicious point;  FALSE  if  test}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11066 \textcolor{comment}{  did not notice anything (in the latter cases fields below are empty).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11067 \textcolor{comment}{* x0[], d[] -\/ arrays of length N which store initial point  and  direction}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11068 \textcolor{comment}{  for line search (d[] can be normalized, but does not have to)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11069 \textcolor{comment}{* stp[], f[] -\/ arrays of length CNT which store step lengths and  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11070 \textcolor{comment}{  values at these points; f[i] is evaluated in x0+stp[i]*d.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11071 \textcolor{comment}{* stpidxa, stpidxb -\/ we  suspect  that  function  violates  C1  continuity}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11072 \textcolor{comment}{  between steps \#stpidxa and \#stpidxb (usually we have  stpidxb=stpidxa+3,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11073 \textcolor{comment}{  with  most  likely  position  of  the  violation  between  stpidxa+1 and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11074 \textcolor{comment}{  stpidxa+2.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11075 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11076 \textcolor{comment}{==========================================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11077 \textcolor{comment}{= SHORTLY SPEAKING: build a 2D plot of (stp,f) and look at it -\/  you  will}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11078 \textcolor{comment}{=                   see where C1 continuity is violated.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11079 \textcolor{comment}{==========================================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11080 \textcolor{comment}{}}

\DoxyCodeLine{11082 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11083 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11084 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11085 \textcolor{comment}{    strrep  -\/   C1 test \#0 "{}strong"{} report}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11086 \textcolor{comment}{    lngrep  -\/   C1 test \#0 "{}long"{} report}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11087 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11088 \textcolor{comment}{  -\/-\/ ALGLIB -\/-\/}}

\DoxyCodeLine{11094 \textcolor{comment}{/*************************************************************************}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11095 \textcolor{comment}{Detailed results of the OptGuard integrity check for nonsmoothness test \#1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11096 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11097 \textcolor{comment}{Nonsmoothness (non-\/C1)  test  \#1  studies  individual  components  of  the}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11098 \textcolor{comment}{gradient computed during line search.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11099 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11100 \textcolor{comment}{When precise analytic gradient is provided this test is more powerful than}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11101 \textcolor{comment}{test \#0  which  works  with  function  values  and  ignores  user-\/provided}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11102 \textcolor{comment}{gradient.  However,  test  \#0  becomes  more   powerful   when   numerical}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11103 \textcolor{comment}{differentiation is employed (in such cases test \#1 detects  higher  levels}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11104 \textcolor{comment}{of numerical noise and becomes too conservative).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11105 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11106 \textcolor{comment}{This test also tells specific components of the gradient which violate  C1}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11107 \textcolor{comment}{continuity, which makes it more informative than \#0, which just tells that}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11108 \textcolor{comment}{continuity is violated.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11109 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11110 \textcolor{comment}{Two reports are returned:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11111 \textcolor{comment}{* a "{}strongest"{} one, corresponding  to  line   search  which  had  highest}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11112 \textcolor{comment}{  value of the nonsmoothness indicator}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11113 \textcolor{comment}{* a "{}longest"{} one, corresponding to line search which  had  more  function}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11114 \textcolor{comment}{  evaluations, and thus is more detailed}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11115 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11116 \textcolor{comment}{In both cases following fields are returned:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11117 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11118 \textcolor{comment}{* positive -\/ is TRUE  when test flagged suspicious point;  FALSE  if  test}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11119 \textcolor{comment}{  did not notice anything (in the latter cases fields below are empty).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11120 \textcolor{comment}{* vidx -\/ is an index of the variable in [0,N) with nonsmooth derivative}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11121 \textcolor{comment}{* x0[], d[] -\/ arrays of length N which store initial point  and  direction}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11122 \textcolor{comment}{  for line search (d[] can be normalized, but does not have to)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11123 \textcolor{comment}{* stp[], g[] -\/ arrays of length CNT which store step lengths and  gradient}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11124 \textcolor{comment}{  values at these points; g[i] is evaluated in  x0+stp[i]*d  and  contains}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11125 \textcolor{comment}{  vidx-\/th component of the gradient.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11126 \textcolor{comment}{* stpidxa, stpidxb -\/ we  suspect  that  function  violates  C1  continuity}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11127 \textcolor{comment}{  between steps \#stpidxa and \#stpidxb (usually we have  stpidxb=stpidxa+3,}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11128 \textcolor{comment}{  with  most  likely  position  of  the  violation  between  stpidxa+1 and}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11129 \textcolor{comment}{  stpidxa+2.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11130 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11131 \textcolor{comment}{==========================================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11132 \textcolor{comment}{= SHORTLY SPEAKING: build a 2D plot of (stp,f) and look at it -\/  you  will}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11133 \textcolor{comment}{=                   see where C1 continuity is violated.}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11134 \textcolor{comment}{==========================================================================}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11135 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11136 \textcolor{comment}{INPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11137 \textcolor{comment}{    state   -\/   algorithm state}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11138 \textcolor{comment}{}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11139 \textcolor{comment}{OUTPUT PARAMETERS:}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11140 \textcolor{comment}{    strrep  -\/   C1 test \#1 "{}strong"{} report}}
\DoxyCodeLine{11141 \textcolor{comment}{    lngrep  -\/   C1 test \#1 "{}long"{} report}}
